src: recovery on the horizon for sa vukuzenzele unnamed the jacaranda trees are in full bloom across the nation’s capital, heralding the start of summer.
tgt: tsosoloso e motjheng bakeng sa afrika borwa vukuzenzele unnamed difate tsa jacaranda di thuntse hohle motsemoholong wa naha ena, e leng letshwao la hore ho kena lehlabula.

src: after a long and difficult winter, the beginning of a new season should fill us with optimism.
tgt: kamora hore ho fete mari ha a malelele a bile a le boima, mathwaso a sehla se setjha a tshwanela ho re fa tshepo .

src: when the national state of disaster was declared in march, our immediate priority was to contain the spread of the virus and provide emergency relief to citizens, communities, workers and businesses.
tgt: ha ho ne ho tsebahatswa ka maemo a koduwa ya naha ka tlhakubele, ntho e neng e le ka sehloohong di sa tloha e ne e le ya hore re kgine ho ata ha kokwanahloko ena re be re fane ka kimollo ya tshoha nyetso ho baahi, setjhabeng, ho basebetsi le dikgwebong.

src: over the course of eight months and with the support of our social partners, we rolled out a comprehensive set of measures to limit the social and economic impact of the pandemic.
tgt: nakong ya dikgwedi tse robedi, ebile e le ka tshehetso ya balekane ba rona kahisa nong, re ile ra anetsa mehato e phethahetseng ya ho kgina sefutho sa kokwanahloko ena setjhabeng le moruong.

src: we massively expanded social protection on a scale that has never been attempted before in this country.
tgt: re ile ra nanabetsa tshire letso ya setjhaba ka sekgahla se neng se e so ka se bonwa naheng ena.

src: we are one of the few countries in the world where the right of access to social security is enshrined in the constitution, and we can be proud that during this grave crisis we gave practical expression to this right in many ways.
tgt: re enngwe ya dinaha tse mmalwa lefa tsheng moo ho yona tokelo ya phihlello ya tshireletso ya setjhaba e fuperweng ke molaotheo, ebile re ka ba motlotlo ka hore nakong ya koduwa ena e mpehadi re ile ra fana ka mohlala o tshwarehang wa tokelo ena ka mekgwa e mengatanyana.

src: in addition to our existing social grants, which reach more than 17 million people every month, we toppedup the old age, disability and child support grants.
tgt: ho eketsa hodima dithuso tse seng di le teng tsa ditjhe lete tsa setjhaba, tse fihlellang bathong ba kahodimo ho 17 milione kgwedi le kgwedi, re ile ra eketsa dithuso tsa ditjhelete tsa metsofe, tsa dikowa le tsa tshehetso ya bana.

src: we rolled out a special coronavirus disease (covid19) social relief of distress grant, which has reached some six million people to date.
tgt: re ile ra nanabetsa dithuso tsa ditjhelete tse kgethehileng tsa kimollo ya setjhaba matshwenyehong a covid19 , tse fihlelletseng bathong ba dimilione tse tsheletseng ho fihlela jwale.

src: this was done within weeks of the national state of disaster being declared.
tgt: sena se ile sa etsuwa na kong ya dibeke tse mmalwa kamora ho phatlalatswa ha maemo a koduwa ya naha.

src: the scale of such an undertaking cannot be understated.
tgt: sefutho sa boikitlaetso boo se ke ke sa shebelwa fatshe.

src: to bring this system online there was extensive collaboration between the south african social security agency, south african revenue service, home affairs and many others.
tgt: ho kopanya tsamaiso ena inthaneteng e ne e le mose betsi o boima wa kopane lo dipakeng tsa lekgotla la tshireletso ya setjhaba la afrika borwa (sassa), tshebeletso ya pokello ya lekgetho ya afrika borwa (sars), lefapha la merero ya lehae le tse ding tse ngata.

src: we set up a fully automated application and disbursement process, and integrated multiple databases, including the national population register and the unemployment insurance fund (uif) database.
tgt: re ile ra qala mosebetsi o phethahetseng wa ho etsa dikopo le wa ditefo, le ho kopanngwa ha mehlodi e mengatanyana ya dideitha, ho akga le ngodiso ya naha ya palo ya setjhaba le mohlo di wa deitha wa inshorense ya ho fellwa ke mosebetsi (uif).

src: we set up new application channels like whatsapp and ussd, and created systems with the commercial banks to enable banking detail verification.
tgt: re ile ra qala methati e metjha ya ho etsa dikopo e kang ya whatsapp le ussd, ra ba ra thea mekgwatsamaiso le dibanka tse kgolo hore di thuse ka tiiseletso ya dintlha tsa motho tsa ho banka.

src: this is a remarkable achievement in a very short space of time.
tgt: ena ke katleho e kgolo ka nako e kgutshwane.

src: alongside the measures we took to protect and sustain livelihoods, we also supported ailing businesses.
tgt: ntle le mehato eo re ileng ra e nka ya ho sireletsa le ho baballa mesebetsi, re ile ra boela ra tshehetsa dikgwebo tse neng di tsherema.

src: we provided relief to small businesses in the form of debt relief, finance, tax payment deferrals and other instruments.
tgt: re ile ra fana ka kimollo dikgwebong tse nyenyane ka mokgwa wa ho di imolla dikolotong, wa ho di tshehetsa ka ditjhelete, wa ho diehisa ditefo tsa le kgetho le mekgwa e meng.

src: we implemented a covid19 loan guarantee scheme to enable businesses to meet their operational expenses during the lockdown, and are currently looking at how this scheme can reach more companies in need.
tgt: re ile ra kenya tlhophiso ya tiiseletso ya kadimo ya ditjhelete ya covid19 tshebetsong, e le ho thusa dikgwebo hore di kgone ho fihlella ditshenyehelo tsa tsona tsa tshebetso nakong ya ho kginwa ha metsamao ya batho le ditshebeletso tseo e seng tsa mantlha, mme ha jwale re ntse re sheba hore na tlhophiso ena e ka di fihlella ha jwang dikhamphane tse ngata le ho feta tse hlokang.

src: we provided income protection to workers and relief to business owners through the temporary employer relief scheme administered by the uif.
tgt: re ile ra fana ka tshireletso ya meputso ya basebetsi le ki mollo ho beng ba dikgwebo ka hore ho etswe tlhophiso ya nakwana ya kimollo ya basebetsi e neng e disitswe ke uif.

src: these were all in direct response to an emergency and were by nature temporary.
tgt: tsena tsohle di ne di arabe la ka kotloloho maemo a tshohanyetso mme e ne e le tsa nakwana feela.

src: some are now coming to an end, while others have been extended as the labour market recovers.
tgt: tse ding jwale di tla pheletsong, ha tse ding ho atollotswe nako ya tsona jwaloka ha mebaraka ya bosebetsi e ntse e hlapho helwa.

src: the measures we implemented went a long way towards protecting our society from the harsh winds of covid19.
tgt: mehato eo re ileng ra e kenya tshebetsong e thusi tse haholo ho sireletseng setjhaba sa habo rona hore se se ke sa tsukutlwa ke maemo a covid19 .

src: the additional grants helped to prevent millions of people from falling below the food poverty line.
tgt: dithuso tsa ditjhelete tse ekeditsweng di thusitse ho thibela hore dimilione tsa batho di se ke tsa kodumela mosimeng wa bofuma ba lephako.

src: had we not intervened to secure livelihoods and save businesses, the living conditions of our people and the circumstances of thousands of businesses would have been considerably worse.
tgt: ha re ne re sa ka ra kena dipakeng ho sireletsa mese betsi le ho pholosa dikgwebo, maemo a ho phela a batho ba habo rona le maemo a dikete kete tsa dikgwebo a ka be a mpefetse le ho feta.

src: now we are in a transition from relief to recovery.
tgt: jwale re mothating wa phetoho ya ho tloha kimo llong ho ya boiphumanong.

src: the emergency measures we put in place have laid a firm foundation on which to rebuild our economy.
tgt: mehato ya tshohanyetso eo re ileng ra e kenya tshebe tsong e radile motheo o ti ileng oo re tla ahella moruo wa habo rona hodima ona.

src: as our focus now shifts to the implementation of the economic reconstruction and recovery plan, our priority will be to stimulate growth and create jobs.
tgt: jwaloka ha tsepamiso ya rona ya maikutlo jwale e feto hetse ho kenngweng tshebe tsong ha leano la kahobotjha le ntlafatso ya moruo, ntlha ya rona e ka sehloohong e tla ba ho susumetsa kgolo le ho thea mesebetsi.

src: there has already been progress in a number of areas.
tgt: ho se ho e na le kgatelopele mapatlelong a mangata nyana.

src: we are seeing new funding commitments for infrastructure development following an infrastructure project roundtable last week.
tgt: re bona boitlamo bo botjha ba ho kenya tjhelete bakeng sa kaho ya meralo ya motheo kamora motshetshetho o bileng teng bekeng e fetileng o neng o le mabapi le projeke ya meralo ya motheo.

src: a number of employment programmes under the presidential employment stimulus have started.
tgt: mananeo a mangatanyana a kgiro a katlasa ditsiane tsa kgiro tsa moporesidente a se a qadile.

src: we are pushing ahead with economic reforms in areas such as energy and telecommunications.
tgt: re hahamalla pele ka ditlhabollo tsa moruo mapatlelong a kang a eneji le a dikgokahanyo tsa mehala.

src: plans are being converted to action and commitments are being reflected in jobs and opportunities.
tgt: merero e fetolwa hore e be diketso ha boikitlaetso bona bo bonahala mesebetsing le menyetleng.

src: it is all the more critical at this time, more so with the festive season approaching, that we do not become the architects of our own undoing.
tgt: tsohle di hlokolotsi haho lwanyane mothating wa jwale, haholoholo jwaloka ha ho atamela sehla sa monyaka wa mafelo a selemo, hore re se ke ra fetoha baitshenyetsi.

src: the greatest vigilance is required from us all to keep the virus at bay.
tgt: phadimeho e kgolo e a hlokeha ho rona bohle, re tsebe ho boloka kokwanahlo ko ena e le hojana le rona.

src: a resurgence at any scale will not just dramatically reverse our health gains.
tgt: ho ropoha botjha ha yona neng kapa neng ha ho no busetsa morao dikatleho tsa rona tsa bophelo bo botle feela, empa ho tla kwebetella makgabane a tsosoloso ya moruo a seng a hlahelletse, ho be ho re tlose mathwasong a selemo ho re busetse morao mariheng.

src: it will choke the green shoots of economic recovery that have emerged, and take us back from spring to winter.
tgt: ho thibela leqhubu la bobedi la ditshwaetso tsa covid19 , re tlameha ho ikamahanya le ditataiso tse ntseng di le teng tsa bophelo bo botle ba setjhaba.

src: when we fail to wear a mask at a social gathering, when we attend crowded events, we are not only putting ourselves and others at risk.
tgt: haeba re hloleha ho kgwesa sekwahelanko le molomo moo ho kgobokaneng batho, haeba re ya diketsahalong tseo ho tsona ho subuhle llaneng batho, ha re ipee borona le ba bang feela tlokotsing, re boela re bea le tsosoloso ya moruo wa habo rona kotsing.

src: let us all continue to play our part.
tgt: bohle ha re nneng re tswe lepele ho etsa letsoho la monna.

src: the positive actions of wearing a mask, of maintaining social distancing and of regular hand washing helped us overcome the worst effects of the pandemic.
tgt: diketso tse ntle tsa ho kgwe sa sekwahelanko le molomo, tsa ho qaqolohana le tsa ho hatlela matsoho kgafetsa di re thusitse ho fenya ditla morao tse mpempe tsa sewa sena.

src: they are still our best defence.
tgt: e ntse e le tsona tseo e leng thebe ya rona e ntle ka ho fetisisa.

src: let us remember the sacrifices we all had to make to contain the spread of the virus in the early days.
tgt: ha re hopoleng boitelo boo bohle re ileng ra tlameha ho bo etsa e le ho kgina ho ata ha kokwanahloko ena ma tsatsing a yona a pele.

src: even as most social and economic activity has resumed, we must still observe all the health measures.
tgt: esita leha boholo ba dike tsahalo tsa kahisano le tsa moruo di thakgohile hape, re ntse re tshwanela ho hlo mpha mehato yohle ya bophelo bo botle.

src: healthdrink water to avoid dehydration allison cooper severe heat and not drinking enough fluids can lead to dehydration and heatstroke, which can be fatal.
tgt: nwaa metsi hore o qobe kgaello ya metsi mmeleng allison cooper lebatama le leholo le ho se nwe mekedikedi e lekaneng, di ka baka kgaello ya metsi mmeleng esita le ho shwa lehlakore ho bakwang ke motjheso.

src: according to the western cape department of health, the summer heat brings with it a high risk of dehydration, which is a harmful loss of water in the body.
tgt: ho ya ka lefapha la bophelo bo botle la kapa bophirimela, motjheso wa lehlabula o tla le kotsi e kgolo ya kgaello ya metsi mmeleng, e leng tahlehelo e kotsi ya metsi mmeleng.

src: dehydration is usually caused by not drinking enough liquids to replenish the water lost by sweating.
tgt: hangata kgaello ya metsi mmeleng e bakwa ke ho se nwe mekedikedi e lekaneng e le ho busa metsi a mmele o a lahlang ha motho a fufulelwa.

src: it can also be caused by an illness, that causes vomiting or diarrhoea; and by sweating from a fever.
tgt: e ka nna ya bakwa le ke ho kula ho bakang lehlatso/letshollo; le ho fufulelwa ka lebaka la feberu.

src: the loss of body fluids does not only occur during hard physical activities, but can also result from walking, gardening or riding a bike, especially in hot or humid conditions.
tgt: ho lahlehelwa ke maro a mmele ha ho etsahale feela dinakong tsa ha mmele o sebetsa ka thata, empa ho ka nna ha bakwa ke ho tsamaya ka maoto sebaka se seleletsana, ho sebetsa ka jareteng kapa ho palama baesekele, haholoholo ha ho tjhesa kapa ho le mongobo.

src: when you are dehydrated, your body cannot function as usual.
tgt: ha o haellwa ke metsi mmeleng, mmele wa hao o ke ke wa sebetsa jwaloka tlwaelo.

src: children younger than five, the elderly and people working outdoors are especially vulnerable to dehydration and heatstroke (a condition caused when your body overheats).
tgt: bana ba katlase ho dilemo tse hlano, metsofe le batho ba sebetsang lepalapaleng ke bona ba tlokotsing e kgolo ya ho fokollwa ke metsi le ho shwa lehlakore ho bakwang ke motjheso (e leng lefu le bakwang ke motjheso o fetisisang mmeleng wa hao).

src: heatstroke is a medical emergency.
tgt: ho shwa lehlakore ho bakwang ke motjheso ke maemo a hlokang thuso ya bongaka ka tshohanyetso.

src: seek medical help immediately for any of these symptoms: feeling confused or your speech starts to become slow and unclear.
tgt: batla thuso ya bongaka hanghang haeba o na le letshwao lefe kapa lefe ho ana: ho ikutlwa o ferekane kapa mokgwa oo o buang ka ona o qala ho sisitheha o bile o sa hlake.

src: nausea and vomiting.
tgt: ho nyekelwa ke pelo le ho hlatsa.

src: rapid, shallow breathing.
tgt: ho hema ka potlako, ha boima.

src: heart starts to race.
tgt: pelo e qala ho otla ka potlako.

src: a throbbing headache.
tgt: ho tshwarwa ke hlooho e mpe.

src: dehydration warning signssome of the early warning signs of dehydration include: feeling thirsty and lightheaded.
tgt: matshwao a bontshang kgaello ya metsi mmelenga mang a matshwao a pele a bontshang kgaello ya metsi mmeleng a akga: ho ikutlwa o nyorilwe le modikadikwane.

src: a dry mouth.
tgt: ho oma molomo.

src: tiredness.
tgt: mokgathala.

src: having dark coloured, strongsmelling urine.
tgt: ho ba le moroto o mmala o leroothonyana, o bile o na le lephoka.

src: passing urine less often than usual.
tgt: ho rota ha mmalwa ho feta tlwaelo.

src: to stay hydrated and avoid heatstroke you should: drink more water than you usually do on hot days.
tgt: hore o dule o na le metsi mmeleng o be o qobe ho shwa lehlakore ho bakwang ke motjheso, o tshwanela ho: nwa metsi a mangata ho feta tlwaelo, ha ho tjhesa.

src: stay inside or in shaded areas.
tgt: dula ka tlung kapa moriting.

src: always carry a bottle of water with you and drink regularly.
tgt: tshwara botlolo ya metsi hohle moo o yang teng mme o a nwe kgafetsa.

src: take regular breaks from the sun if you work outside.
tgt: haeba o sebetsa lepalapaleng, kgefutsa kgafetsa o nne o tlohe letsatsing.

src: cool yourself down by using a spray bottle.
tgt: iphodise ka ho sebedisa botlolo ya ho inyanyatsa.

src: babies and childrenparents and caregivers should pay extra attention to children and babies, to make sure they are hydrated.
tgt: masea le banabatswadi le bahlokomedi ba bana ba tlameha ho tsepamisa maikutlo haholwanyane baneng le maseeng, ho netefatsa hore ba na le metsi mmeleng.

src: breastfeeding moms should feed their babies more frequently when it is very hot.
tgt: ha ho tjhesa haholo, batswetse ba nyantshang ba tlameha ho nyantsha masea a bona kgafetsa.

src: keep children indoors or in the shade, dress them in light clothing and wipe them down with a damp cloth to help them stay cool.
tgt: bolokang bana ka matlung kapa moriting, le ba apese diaparo tse bobebe le be le ba hlakole mebeleng ka lesela le mongobo e le ho ba thusa hore ba dule ba phodile.

src: remember to apply sunscreen when they go outdoors.
tgt: hopolang ho ba tlotsa ka setlolo se ba sireletsang bohaleng ba letsatsi ha ba tswela kantle.

src: if children younger than five have watery stools, keep vomiting and are tired, seek medical help immediately.
tgt: haeba bana ba katlase ho dilemo tse hlano ba tsholla, ba hlatsa kgafetsa ba bile ba tepelletse, tsa mo batla thuso ya bongaka hanghang.

src: also seek immediate medical care if your baby is unable to breastfeed or has sunken eyes and a sunken soft spot (fontanelle) on its head.
tgt: hape, batla thuso ya bongaka hanghang haeba lesea la hao le sa kgone ho nyanya letswele kapa mahlo a lona a hohlometse le bile le bothetse phuana hloohong.

src: in children, other dehydration warning signs include: a dry or sticky mouth.
tgt: baneng teng, matshwao a mang a ho haellwa ke metsi mmeleng a akga: molomo o ommeng kapa o namathelang.

src: sa overcoming hiv and aids vukuzenzele unnamed as we continue our efforts to manage the devastating coronavirus pandemic, we cannot ignore the other public health challenges that our country faces.
tgt: afrika borwa e hlola hiv le aids vukuzenzele unnamed ha re ntse retswella ka maiteko a rona a ho laola sewa sena se re thefutseng sa kokwanahloko ya corona , ha hona hore re ka iphapanyetsa diphephetso tse ding tsa bophelo bo botle tseo naha ya rona e kopanang le tsona.

src: for more than three dec ades, our country has been engaged in an ongoing struggle against hiv and aids, which has cost many lives and caused great hardship and suffering.
tgt: ka dilemo tse fetang mashome a mararo, esale naha ya rona e ntse e lwantshana le bothata ba phamokate (hiv) le lefu la phamokate (aids), bo ileng ba baka tahlahelo ya maphelo a mangata le ho baka ditsietsi le tshotleho e kgolohadi.

src: since the outbreak of cov id19 in the country, with the nationwide lockdown and the pressure on our health facilities, many hiv , aids and tuberculosis services have suffered.
tgt: ho tloha maqalong a sewa sa covid19 naheng, le ho kwalwa ha naha ka kakaretso le kgatello ho ditsha tsa bophelo bo botle, boholo ba ditshebeletso tsa hiv , aids le lefuba (tb) di ile tsa kgahlamelwa hampe.

src: this has posed a challenge for people testing and starting antiretroviral treatment.
tgt: sena se bakile phephetso ho batho ba etsang diteko le ho qala ka pheko ya meriana ya arv .

src: many people found it difficult to collect their medicines and fewer people accessed other services, such as voluntary male medical circumcision.
tgt: boholo ba batho ba fumane ho le boima ho phaka meriana ya bona mme ke batho ba mmalwa feela ba ileng ba kgona ho fumantshwa ditshebeletso tse itseng, tse jwalo ka ho bolotswa ha banna ka bongaka ka boithaupi.

src: at the same time, there are many lessons that have been learnt from our public health response to the coronavirus pandemic that can strengthen our fight against hiv and tb.
tgt: ka mokgwa o tshwanang, re boetse re ithutile dintho tse ngata ho tswa ho karabelo ya rona ya ditshebeletso tsa bophelo bo botle ka sewa sa kokwanahloko ya corona tse ka matlafatsang ntwa ya rona kgahlano le hiv le tb.

src: south africa continues to have the largest number of people living with hiv in the world.
tgt: afrika borwa e tswella ho ba le palo e kgolo ya batho ba phelang ka hiv lefatsheng.

src: it is encouraging, however, that over the last decade we made progress in reducing the number of new hiv infections in the population by nearly 60%.
tgt: feela, ho a kgothatsa hore dilemong tse leshome tse fetileng re ﬁ hletse kgatelopele ho fokotseng palo e ntjha ya ditshwaetso tsa hiv setjhabeng sa rona ka boholo bo batlileng bo lekana le 60%.

src: it is also encouraging that hiv infections in adolescent girls and young women have significantly declined in the last decade.
tgt: ho boela ho kgothatsa hore tshwaetso ya hiv barwetsaneng le dikgarebe e theohile haholo dilemong tse leshome tse fetileng.

src: this is a crucial group because they are much more likely to be at risk of getting hiv .
tgt: sena ke sehlopha sa baahi se bohlokwa haholo hobane ke bona ba ka bang kotsing e kgolokgolo ya ho tshwaetswa ke hiv .

src: our treatment programme has contributed to a reduction in the number of deaths due to aids by 60%.
tgt: lenaneo la rona la pheko le bile le seabo ho fokotseng palo ya mafu a bakwang ke aids ka 60%.

src: there has been a greater reduction in hivrelated deaths among young people.
tgt: ho bile le phokotseho e kgolo mafung a amanang le hiv batjheng.

src: it was possible to reduce the number of deaths because we, together with our partners, have rolled out an extensive antiretroviral programme reaching millions of people living with the disease.
tgt: re ile ra kgonahala ho fokotsa dipalo tsa mafu hobane, ha mmoho le balekane ba rona, re ile ra kenya lenaneo le leholo la meriana ya arv le ileng la ﬁ hlella dimilione tsa batho ba phelang ka lefu lena.

src: at the beginning of the decade, our programme to prevent mother to child transmission (pmtct) of hiv had very low coverage.
tgt: maqalong a dilemo tse leshome, lenaneo la rona la ho thibela tshwaetso ya mme leseeng (pmtct) ka hiv le ne le sa phatlalatswa haholo.

src: now we have one of the highest rates of coverage of pmtct in southern africa, which has substantially reduced rates of infection among children.
tgt: ha jwale re se re ena le palo e hodimodimo ka ho fetisisa dinaheng tsa borwa ba afrika, e leng se fokoditseng haholo dipalo tsa tshwaetso baneng.

src: while we have reduced deaths and new infections, we still are far from reaching the goal we committed ourselves in 2016 of achieving a 75% reduction in hiv infections by 2020. if we succeed in doing so, we are likely to end aids as a public health threat by 2030. unfortunately, we are not there yet.
tgt: le ha feela re fokoditse mafu le ditshwaetso tse ntjha, re ntse re le hole le ho ﬁ hlella maikemisetso a rona ao re ikanneng ka ona ka 2016 a ho ﬁ hlella 75% ya phokotso ya ditshwaetso tsa hiv ka 2020. ha re ka atleha ho etsa sena, re ka kgona ho fedisa aids jwalo ka kotsi e kgahlano le bophelo bo botle ka 2030. ka maswabi, ha re so ﬁ hle moo.

src: we have to do far more to ensure that young people are empowered to prevent infections, including through changing behaviour, accessing condoms and testing regularly.
tgt: re tlameha ho etsa dintho tse ding tse ngata ho netefatsa hore batjha ba rona ba matlafaditswe ka ho thibela ditshwaetso, ho kenyeletsa ho fetola maitshwaro a bona, ho fumantshwa dikgohlopo le ho etsa diteko kgafetsa.

src: we need to make sure that everyone who is infected has access to treatment and care.
tgt: re hloka ho netefatsa hore bohle ba nang le tshwaetso ba fumantshwa pheko le tlhokomelo.

src: we need to work harder on hiv prevention among key populations, including sex workers, men who have sex with men, and people who inject drugs.
tgt: re hloka ho sebetsa ka thatathata ho thibela tshwaetso ya hiv haholoholo ho ditho tsa setjhaba tse nang le kgonahalo e hodimo ya ho tshwaetseha, tse kenyeletsang basebetsi ba rekisang mmele, banna ba etsang thobalano le banna ba bang, le batho ba itlhabang ka dithethefatsi.

src: we must end the stigma and discrimination towards these populations.
tgt: re tlameha ho fedisa sekgobo le kgethollo e kgahlano le batho bana.

src: we cannot hope to end hiv if we ignore the needs, concerns and rights of any part of our population.
tgt: re ka se tshepe feela hore re tla fedisa hiv haeba re iphapanyetsa ditlhoko, dingongoreho le ditokelo tsa karolo e fe kapa e fe ya setjhaba sa rona.

src: south africa needs to increase efforts to medically circumcise young men to reduce their risk of acquiring hiv .
tgt: afrika borwa e hloka ho eketsa maiteko a ho bolotsa bahlankana ka bongaka ho fokotsa kotsi ya bona ya ho tshwaetswa ke hiv .

src: unsafe circumcision should not leave young men with lifelong health problems, and no one should die from circumcision.
tgt: ho bolotswa ho sa bolokehang ha ho a tlameha ho siya bahlankana ba rona ba ena le mathata a bophelo bo botle ka ho sa feleng, mme ha ho motho ya tlameha ho hlokahala ka lebaka la ho bolotswa.

src: we must make sure that young men have safe circumcision.
tgt: re tlameha ho netefatsa hore bahlankana ba rona ba bolotswa ka tsela e bolokehileng.

src: we are encouraged by findings of a recent study on preexposure prophylaxis (prep).
tgt: re kgothaditswe ke sephetho sa diphuputsu tsa hauﬁ nyana tjena tse buang ka meriana ya ho thibela tshwaetseha (prep).

src: unlike antiretroviral treatment that is given to people who are hiv positive, prep involves the regular use of antiretroviral drugs by hiv negative people to prevention infection.
tgt: e fapane ho arv ka ha pheko ya arv e fuwa batho ba nang le tshwaetso ya hiv , prep yona e le pheko e sebediswang kgafetsa ke batho ba senang hiv ho thibela tshwaetso.

src: the study, conducted by scientists from the hiv prevention trials network, found that longacting injections once every eight weeks was better than the daily tablet used for hiv prevention.
tgt: diphuputsu tsena, tse entsweng ke ditsebi tsa saene tsa marangrang a diteko tsa thibelo ya hiv , di fumane hore ho hlajwa ha nngwe ka mora dibeke tse robedi ha diente tse sebetsang ka nako e telele ho betere ho feta ho nwa pidisi e thibelang hiv e nwewang letsatsi le letsatsi.

src: these findings have the potential to significantly strengthen our response to the epidemic.
tgt: diphetho tsena di na le bokgoni bo boholo ba ho ka matlafatsa karabelo ya sewa sena.

src: if we are to succeed in ending aids as a public health threat within the next decade, we need to combine these medical breakthroughs with fundamental changes in behaviour.
tgt: haeba re ikemiseditse ho atleha ho fedisa aids jwalo ka kotsi e kgahlano le bophelo bo botle dilemong tsena tse leshome, re hloka ho kopantsha ditshibollo tsa bongaka le ho fetola maitshwaro ka botebo.

src: we also need to tackle the economic and social conditions that contrib ute to high rates of infection.
tgt: re boela re hloka ho lwantshana le maemo a moru le a bophelo a bakang dipalo tse hodimo tsa tshwaetso.

src: one of our central tasks is to empower adolescent girls and young women, educationally, economically and socially.
tgt: e nngwe ya dithomo tsa rona e ka sehlohlong ke ho matlafatsa barwetsana le dikgarebe, ka thuto, moruo le maemo a bophelo setjhabeng.

src: they need to be able to make their own decisions about every aspect of their lives, including their sexuality and sexual behaviour.
tgt: ba hloka ho kgona ho inkela diqeto ka karolo e nngwe le e nngwe ya maphelo a bona, ho kenyeletsa maikutlo le maitshwaro a bona ka thobalano.

src: ultimately, we will achieve the end of aids through the empowerment of young people, women and other people at risk.
tgt: qetellong, re tla ﬁ hlella phediso ya aids ka ho matlafatsa batjha, basadi le batho ba bang ba kotsing.

src: this includes empowerment through access to information, advice and support.
tgt: sena se kenyeletsa matlafatso ka phumantsho ya lesedi, dikeletso le tshehetso.

src: it includes access to education and economic opportunities, especially for young women.
tgt: se kenyeletsa phumantsho ya thuto le menyetla ya moruo, haholoholo ho barwetsana.

src: another chance to get your matric cathy grosvenor it is never too late to get your matric or to achieve the results you want, is the message behind the department of basic edu cation’s (dbe) second chance matric support programme.
tgt: monyetla o mong hape wa ho phethela materiki wa hao cathy grosvenor nako ya hore o ka phethela materiki wa hao kapa wa fumana sephetho seo o se labalabelang e ntse e le teng, ke molaetsa o tswang ho lenaneo la tshehetso la monyetla wa bobedi wa materiki wa lefapha la thuto ya motheo (dbe).

src: director of the programme, dr sandy malapile, says a matric qualification is an absolute necessity because without it, many doors of opportunity remain closed.
tgt: molaodi wa lenaneo, ngaka sandy malapile, o re lengolo la materiki le bohlokwahlokwa hobane ntle le lona, boholo ba menyetla e tla dula a kwetswe.

src: "sector training and education authorities (setas), tasked with upskilling the nation through skills programmes and apprenticeships, also require that candidates have a matric," says dr malapile.
tgt: "bolaodi ba lekala la thupello le thuto (seta), bo rongweng ka ho ntlafatsa setjhaba ka mananeo a botsebi le borupelli, bo hloka hore barupellwi ba be le materiki," ho rialo ngaka malapile.

src: launched in january 2016, the second chance programme supports anyone – of any age – who wants to achieve or improve a matric qualification, subjectbysubject and on a parttime basis.
tgt: le thakgotswe ka pherekgong 2016, lenaneo la monyetla wa bobedi le tshehetsa bohle – ba dilemo di fe kapa di fe – ba batlang ho fihlella kapa ho ntlafatsa lengolo la bona la materiki, thutong kang mme le ka thuto ya nakwana.

src: there are no costs involved.
tgt: ha ho ditjeho di fe kapa di fe.

src: people who want to im prove their matric results, whether they wrote matric recently or even decades ago.
tgt: batho ba batlang ho ntla fatsa sephetho sa bona sa materiki, ho sa kgathaletsehe hore na ba ngotse materiki ya bona haufinyana tjena kapa dilemo tse leshome tse fetileng.

src: dr malapile explains that a person wanting to obtain an engineering qualification, for in stance, might need to im prove their mathematics mark to qualify for the course.
tgt: ngaka malapile o hlalosa hore motho ya batlang ho ba le lengolo la boenjineri, ho etsa mohlala, o tla hloka ho ntlafatsa matshwao a hae a mmetse hore a kgone ho kena thutong ena.

src: people who failed matric and want a second chance at passing.
tgt: batho ba ileng ba se kgone ho pasa materiki mme ba batla monyetla wa bobedi wa ho pasa.

src: people who left school after passing grade 9 (then standard 7), are 21 or older, and wish to obtain their matric.
tgt: batho ba tloheletseng sekolo ka mora ho pasa ke reite 9 (sehlopha sa bo7), ba dilemo tse 21 kapa tse fetang, mme ba labalabela ho fumana lengolo la bona la materiki.

src: how to get startedregister at one of the 75 dis trict education offices across the country or online at this website: www.
tgt: o ka qala jwangingodisa ho e nngwe ya dikantoro tse 75 tsa disetereke tsa thuto naheng ka bophara kapa marangrang a inthanete ho websaete ena: www.

src: eservices.
tgt: eservices.

src: gov.
tgt: gov.

src: za.
tgt: za.

src: registration opened on 1 october and will close in february 2021. learners either study on their own or at one of the 133 second chance centres where facetoface learning takes place afterhours and on weekends.
tgt: ho ingodisa ho butsi ka la1 mphalane mme ho tla kwala ka hlakola 2021. baithuti ba ka ipalla ka bo bona kapa ba ithutela ho e nngwe ya ditsi tse 133 tsa lenaneo la tshehetso la monyetla wa bobedi wa materiki moo ba tla rutwang ke matitjhere ka kotloloho ka mora dihora tsa tshebetso kapa ka mafelo a beke.

src: dr malapile says only the top performing teachers in each district are employed at these centres.
tgt: ngaka malapile o re ho hiruwe matitjhere a hlwahlwa feela ho tswa seterekeng kang ho ruta ditsing tsena.

src: the centres are not available in every town and village, but are located in areas where the greatest number of people have registered, which means their location could change each year.
tgt: ditsi tsena ha di fumananehe ditoropong kapa metseng yohle, empa di fumaneha dibakeng tseo e leng hore ho bile le palo e hodimodimo ya batho ba ingodisitseng, ho bolelang sebaka sa boithutelo se ka fetoha selemo le selemo.

src: both facetoface learners and learners who study at home have access to a full range of study support services, from lessons broadcast on radio and television at specific times; to downloadable online material; and, for those without access to computers, printers and the inter net−printed study material is sent to them by the dbe.
tgt: baithuti ba rutwang ke matitjhere ka kotloloho le ba ithutelang lapeng ba fumantshwa ditshebeletso tsa tshehetso ya dithuto tse phethahetseng ka ho tshwana, ho tloha ho kgaso ya dithuto seyalemoyeng le telebesheneng ka dinako tse itseng; ho ya ho disebediswa tse fumanwang inthaneteng; mme, le ho ba senang dikhompiyutha, dihatisi leinthanete – mme ba romellwa dibukana tsa ho ithuta tse hatisitsweng ke dbe.

src: people with a computer but no internet or data, may request a cd with all the study material, which will be mailed to them.
tgt: batho ba nang le khompiyutha empa ba hloka inthanete kapa data, ba ka kopa cd e nang le dibukana tsa ho ithuta tsohle, mme ba tle e romellwa.

src: "many adult learners may not have lots of time to devote to their studies.
tgt: "boholo ba baithuti ba batho ba baholo bo hloka nako ya ho shebana le dithuto tsa bona feela.

src: luck ily, they may decide how many subjects they want to do a year because they do not have to complete their matric within a set time.
tgt: ka lehlohonolo, ba ka kgona ho nka qeto ya hore na ke dithuto tse kae tseo ba batlang ho di etsa ka selemo hobane ha ba behelwa nako eo ba tlamehang ho phethela materiki ya bona ka yona."

src: "once registered, the dbe will help each older learner choose the subjects they want to do and explain which ones are compulsory.
tgt: ha ba se ba ingodisitse, dbe e tla thusa mothuti e moholo kang ho kgetha dithuto tseo a batlang ho di etsa le ho mo hlalosetsa hore na ke di fe tsa setlamo.

src: on qualifying, people who left school after 2008 receive a national senior certificate and those who left school earlier, receive an amended senior certificate.
tgt: ha ba se ba atlehile dithutong tsa bona, batho ba tlohetseng sekolo ka mora 2008 ba fumantshwa setifikeiti se phahameng sa naha, mme ba tlohetseng sekolo pele ho moo, ba fumantshwa setifikeiti se fetotsweng se phahameng.

src: however, dr malapile says both qualifications carry the same weight and, depending on the subjects taken and marks achieved, can be used to apply to universities and colleges.
tgt: empa, ngaka malapile o re mangolo ka bobedi, a na le boleng bo phahameng ka ho tshwana, ho ya ka dithuto tse kgethuweng le matshwao a fihleletsweng, a ka sebediswa ho kenya dikopa tsa diyunivesithi le dikholetjhi.

src: giving second chancesthe dbe holds community roadshows to encourage people to enrol for the second chance programme.
tgt: ho nehelana ka menyetla ya bobedidbe e tshwara mananeo a dipontsho a mabileng a setjhaba ho kgothaletsa batho ho ingodisetsa lenaneo la tshehetso la monyetla wa bobedi wa materiki.

src: tertiary education institutions and setas are invited to provide as much information as possible to interested people.
tgt: ditsha tsa thuto e phahameng le diseta di mengwelwa ho tla nehelana ka lesedi le ngata ka mokgwa o kgonehang ho batho ba nang lekgahleho.

src: at many of these roadshows, minister angie mot shekga was asked by youth to introduce programmes that could assist young people to be more employable, says dr malapile.
tgt: ho boholo ba mananeo ana a dipontsho a mebileng, letona angie motshekga o ile a koptjwa ke batjha ho phatlalatsa mananeo a ka thusang batjha ho kgona ho fumana menyetla e mengata ya mesebetsi, ho rialo ngaka malapile.

src: in response, the dbe is launching a skills development programme this year that will target about 3.4 million young people who are not in employment, education or training.
tgt: ho arabela sena, dbe e thakgola lenaneo la ntshetsopele ya botsebi selemong sena le ikemiseditseng ho fihlella batjha ba dimillione tse3.4 ba hlokang mesebetsi, thuto le thupello.

src: courses will range from life skills – covering topics such as how to write a cv and what to do at a job interview; to basic skills courses, such as shoe repair, basic itc and literacy.
tgt: dithuto di tla kenyeletsa mekgwa ya ho iphedisa – ho kenyeletsa dihlooho tse jwalo ka ho ngola cv le seo o tlamehang ho se etsa inthaviung ya mosebetsi; ho ya ho dithuto tsa botsebi ba motheo, jwalo ka ho lokisa dieta, tsebo ya ho sebedisa khomphiutha (ict), le le tsebo ya ho bala le ho ngola.

src: did you know?
tgt: vna o ne o tseba?

src: regardless of whether you left school in the 60s or recently, you have to study the current curriculum.
tgt: ho sa kgathaletsehe hore na o tloheletse sekolo dilemong tsa bo 1960 kapa haufinyananyana, o tlameha ho ithuta ho latela khurikhulamu ya ha jwale.

src: a better 2021 for all south africans the first weeks of the year have been difficult for all south africans.
tgt: 2021 e betere ho maafrika borwa ohledibeke tsa pele tsa selemo e bile tse boima ho maafrika borwa ohle.

src: vukuzenzele unnamed the coronavirus pandemic has gotten worse, with new infections increasing far faster and far higher than before.
tgt: vukuzenzele unnamed koduwa ya kokwanahloko ya corona e ile ya mpefala haholo, mme le tshwaetso tse ntjha tsa eketseha ka sekgahla se seholo se fetang sa pele.

src: hospitals have been under great strain as more people have needed medical attention.
tgt: dipetlele di ile tsa ba tlasa kgatello e kgolo jwalo ka ha bongata ba batho bo ile ba hloka tlhokomelo ya bongaka.

src: while most economic sectors have been able to operate again for several months, it will take some time for the economy to recover and for lost jobs to be restored.
tgt: leha dikarolo tse ngata tsa moruo di kgonne ho sebetsa hape dikgwedi tse mmalwa, ho sa tla nka nako hore moruo o boele o setlele esitana le yona mesebetsi e lahlehileng hore e boele e fumanehe.

src: as the new year starts, many families are still feeling the effects of the pandemic on their lives and livelihoods.
tgt: jwalo ka ha selemo se setjha se qala, malapa a mangata a ntse a utlwela ditlamorao tsa koduwa ena maphelong a ona le moo a phelang teng.

src: the world is now entering the second year of the coronavirus pandemic.
tgt: lefatshe ka bophara jwale le kena selemong sa bobedi sa koduwa ena ya kokwanahloko ya corona.

src: for south africa, as for most countries around the world, the year 2021 will be extremely challenging.
tgt: afrika borwa jwalo ka dinaha tse ding tse ngata tsa lefatshe, selemo sa 2021 e tla ba se nang le phephetso e kgolo haholo.

src: the second wave of covid19 infections may well be followed by further waves, which will threaten both the health of our people and the recovery of our economy.
tgt: leqhubu la bobedi la tshwaetso ya covid19 le ka latelwa ke a mang a ka kgahlapetsang maphelo a batho ba rona le yona tsoseletso ya moruo wa rona.

src: difficult as this year will be, i am certain that we will overcome the pandemic and set our country firmly on the path to recovery.
tgt: selemo sena se le boima se le jwalo, empa ke na le tshepo ya hore re tla e hlola koduwa ena mme re thehe tsela e yang tsoseletsong.

src: my confidence comes from the south african people.
tgt: tshepo ya ka e tswa ho maafrika borwa.

src: if i look at how south africans responded to this crisis from the moment the virus arrived on our shores, i have no doubt that we have the resilience, discipline and ability to defeat this disease.
tgt: ha ke sheba tsela eo maafrika borwa a ileng a arabela ka yona bothateng bona ho tloha ha kokwanahloko ena e ne e fihla naheng ya habo rona, ha ke qeaqee hore re na le mamello, tiisetso esitana le bona bokgoni ba ho hlola bohloko bona.

src: certainly there were exceptions, but the vast majority of south africans understood the need for restrictions on their movement and activities, and complied with the regulations that we had to put in place.
tgt: teng ho bile le phapang moo le moo, empa bongata ba maafrika borwa bo utlwisisitse tlhokeho ya ho kginwa ha metsamao le mesebetsi ya ona, mme a ikobela le melao e behilweng.

src: even more important than compliance, most south africans took responsibility for themselves and for others, following advice on issues like social distancing, wearing a mask and hand washing.
tgt: se bileng bohlokwa haholo le ho feta ho ikobela melao, ke hore maafrika borwa a mangata a ile a nka boikarabelo bakeng sa ona le ba bang, a latela dikeletso mabapi le dintlha tse kang ho se atamellane le batho ba bang, ho apara sefonyo esitana le ho hlapa matsoho.

src: and where we fell short, we have, sadly, seen the consequences.
tgt: moo re ileng ra haellwa teng, ka bomadimabe, re bone ditlamorao tse bosula.

src: we now know about the risks of closed spaces and crowded gatherings, of not wearing masks and not keeping our distance from others.
tgt: re a tseba jwale kotsi ya tshubuhlellano le ho ba mokguping, ho se apare sefonyo le ho se ipehe thoko le ba bang.

src: we now know much more about the disease and how to prevent its spread.
tgt: jwale se re tseba haholwanyane ka bohloko bona le hore re ka thibela ho ata ha bona jwang.

src: and despite what one could call ‘pandemic fatigue’, we are no less determined as south africans to do what needs to be done.
tgt: le ho siya taba ya hore re se re 'kgathetse ke koduwa' ena, jwalo ka maafrika borwa, re na le tshepo ya ho etsa se tlamehang ho etswa.

src: as we adhere even more rigorously to the basic prevention measures, we will also be rolling out a mass vaccination campaign.
tgt: jwalo ka ha re ntse re ikobela ka thata dipehelo tsa ho thibela bohloko bona, re boetse hape re kena letsholong le leholo la ho hlaba setjhaba ka ente e thibelang bohloko bona.

src: as more and more people are vaccinated, we will both save lives and progressively reduce the risk of infection across the population.
tgt: ho entwa ha batho ka bongata, ho tla pholosa maphelo a mangata, ho boele hape ho theole kotsi ya tshwaetso setjhabeng.

src: getting enough vaccines as quickly as possible – and making sure that they reach the people who need them – will be one of the biggest tasks of the year.
tgt: ho fumana ente e lekaneng ka potlako – le ho netefatsa hore e finyella bathong ba e hlokang – e tla ba o mong wa mesebetsi e meholo selemong sena.

src: this will be particularly challenging as every country in the world is clamouring to secure a limited supply of vaccines.
tgt: sena e tla ba bothatanyana jwalo ka ha dinaha tsohle tsa lefatshe di leka ho fumana ente ena e so kang e fumaneha ka bongata.

src: but we are hard at work with partners in business, labour and civil society to make this happen.
tgt: leha ho le jwalo, re sebetsa mmoho le mahlahana a rona ho tsa kgwebo, mekgatlo ya basebetsi le ya setjhaba ho fihlela sena.

src: we are working on several fronts to get vaccines, including through the global covax facility, the african union initiative and through our own engagements with vaccine manufacturers.
tgt: re leka ho fumana ente ena dibakeng tse fapafapaneng tse kenyeletsang mokgatlo wa matjhaba wa covax, mokgatlong wa dinaha tsa afrika re boetse hape re buisana ka kotloloho le bahlahisi ba diente tsena.

src: as we act together to overcome the pandemic, we will need to work together to rebuild and transform our economy.
tgt: jwalo ka ha re sebetsa mmoho ho lwantsha koduwa ena, re tlameha ho boela re sebetsa mmoho ho tsoseletsa le ho fetola moruo wa rona.

src: we have both the ability and the will to stimulate economic activity, grow our economy and create jobs.
tgt: re na le bokgoni le tabatabelo tsa ho tsosolosa le ho nyolla moruo esitana le hona ho theha mesebetsi.

src: public finances are under extreme strain, now even more so because of the cost of our health response to covid19 and the social and economic relief measures we put in place to assist businesses and poor households.
tgt: ditjhelete tsa setjhaba di tlasa kgatello e kgolo, haholoholo ka lebaka la ditjeho tsa bophelo bo botle twantshanong le covid19 esitana le tshehetso eo re fanang ka yona dikgwebong le malapeng a futsanehileng.

src: the contraction of the economy also meant that tax revenue has declined significantly.
tgt: ho putlama hona ha moruo ho boetse ho bolela le ho theoha haholo ha lekgetho le kenang.

src: there are some parts of the economy that will take longer to recover due to lower global demand generally and restrictions on international travel.
tgt: ho na le dikarolo tse ding tsa moruo tse tla nka nako ho tsoseletseha ka lebaka la sekgahla se tlase sa tlhokeho ya ditshebeletso tsa tsona lefatsheng ka bophara, le ka lebaka la ho kginwa ha maeto a matjhaba.

src: that is why we need to be innovative and focused in our plans to rebuild the economy.
tgt: ke ka hona re tlamehang ho shebana le ntjhafatso esitana le ona maano a rona a ho aha moruo botjha.

src: significantly, the economic reconstruction and recovery plan that we announced in october last year is based on broad consensus among all social part ners on the actions needed to rebuild the economy.
tgt: hantlentle, leano la tsoseletso ya moruo leo re le phatlaladitseng ka mphalane ngwahola, le thehilwe tumellanong le mahlahana a rona ka mehato e hlokahalang kahong botjha ya moruo.

src: this lays a firm basis for effective cooperation that draws on the resources, capabilities and energies of all sections of society.
tgt: sena ke motheo o matla wa tshebedisano mmoho e radilweng ka disebediswa, bokgoni le matla dikarolong tsohle tsa setjhaba.

src: we are seeing this in various practical ways.
tgt: re bona sena se etsahala ka ditsela tse fapafapaneng.

src: for example, we have been working closely with private funders and multilateral development institutions to prepare infrastructure projects in areas like transport, human settlements, water and telecommunications.
tgt: mohlala, haesale re sebedisana mmoho le batshehetsi ba ikemetseng ba ditjhelete le mekgatlo e fapafapaneng ya ntshetsopele ho rala diprojeke tsa dibopeho tsa motheo dikarolong tse kang tsa dipalangwang, ho dudiswa ha batho, metsi le tsa kgokahano.

src: using the infrastructure fund as one of the vehicles, we are developing funding models for these projects that draw on several sources in both the public and private sectors.
tgt: ka ho sebedisa letlole la dibopeho tsa motheo jwalo ka o mong wa mekgwa ya tshebetso, re theha mekga ya diprojeke mehloding e fapafapaneng ho tswa ka bobedi, mmusong le makaleng a ikemetseng.

src: this is particularly important at a time when public finances are limited.
tgt: sena se bohlokwa haholo nakong eo ditjhelete tsa setjhaba di fokolang.

src: the presidential employment stimulus is another example of partnership in action.
tgt: o mong wa mehlala ya tshebedisano mmoho ena ke leano la kgiro la mopresidente.

src: understanding that it will take time for economic growth to translate into private sector employment, we have launched the employment stimulus to start creat ing work opportunities now.
tgt: jwalo ka ha re utlwisisa hore ho tla nka nako e telele hore kgolo ya moruo e thehe menyetla ya mesebetsi lekaleng le ikemetseng, re thehile leano la kgiro ho qala ho theha menyetla ya mesebetsi hona jwale.

src: this programme is being coordinated from the presiden cy, but is being implemented by a range of government departments and different spheres.
tgt: leano lena le laolwa ke kantoro ya mopresidente, empa le kengwa tshebetsong ke mafapha a fapafapaneng maemong a fapafapaneng a mmuso.

src: through this programme, tens of thousands of unemployed people are able to both earn and learn as they provide valuable social services.
tgt: ka lona leano lena, dikete tse balwang ka mashome tsa batho ba sa sebetseng di kgona ho fumana manyane le hona ho ithuta jwalo ka ha ba fana ka ditshebeletso tsa bohlokwa setjhabeng.

src: in time, this programme will include a ‘social employment’ part, where we will partner with other social actors to employ people in a variety of activities – from improving food security, to tackling genderbased violence to upgrading informal settlements – that all contribute to the common good.
tgt: ha nako e ntse e tsamaya, leano lena le tla kenyeletsa karolo ya 'kgiro ya setjhaba' moo re tlang ho sebedisana mmoho le basebeletsi setjhabeng ho hira batho ho etsa mesebetsi e fapafapaneng – ho tloha ntlafatsong ya pokeletso ya dijo ho ya twantshong ya tlhekefetso ya bonng ho isa ntlafatsong ya bodulo dibakeng tsa baipehi – tseo kaofela e leng ketso tse molemo haholo.

src: all this work is being reinforced by an aggressive focus on those economic reforms that will have the greatest focus on growth.
tgt: mosebetsi ona kaofela o matlafaditswe ke ho shebana ka matla le dintlafatso tsa moruo tse tla shebana le kgolo ya ona.

src: these include the expansion of electricity generation capacity, making our ports more efficient and competitive, improving access to affordable broadband, and improving turnaround times for water, mining and other licenses.
tgt: tsona di kenyeletsa kgudiso ya ho fehlwa ha motlakase, ho etsa boemakepe bo sebetsang ka nepo le bo maemong, ho ntlafatsa kgokahano e ditjeho di fihlellehang ya inthanethe, mmoho le kgutsufatso ya nako ya ho fumana dilayesense tsa phepelo ya metsi, merafo le tse ding.

src: these efforts are being coordinated and monitored jointly by my office and national treasury.
tgt: maano ana a laolwa le hona ho behwa leihlo ka kopanelo ke kantoro ya ka esitana le kantoro ya naha ya matlotlo.

src: there is much to be done in the year ahead.
tgt: mosebetsi o tlamehang ho etswa o sa le moholo ha selemo se ntse se tsamaya.

src: and we should be in no doubt that we will have to confront many daunting challenges.
tgt: ka hodimo ho moo, re tlameha ho tseba hore ha ho qeaqeo, re tla teana le diphephetso tse ngata.

src: parenting a child with epilepsy allison cooper while it may be a shock for a family to learn that a child has epilepsy, you can build an understanding, loving and accepting environment in which your child can grow and believe in their ability to succeed.
tgt: ho hodisa ngwana ya nang le bohloko ba sethwathwa allison cooper leha ba lelapa ba ka tshoswa ke taba ya hore ho na le ngwana ya nang le bohloko ba sethwathwa ka lapeng, o le motswadi o ka etsa hore ngwana wa hao a holele lapeng le ikamohetseng, le nang le lerato e bile le na le kutlwisiso ho etsa hore ngwana hao a hole a dumela hore o na le bokgoning ba ho atleha.

src: according to epilepsy south africa, parents could be concerned about their child’s future and find epilepsy difficult to accept or talk about.
tgt: ho ya ka ba epilepsy south africa, batswadi ba ka iphumana ba ngongoreha ka bokamoso ba ngwana mme ba fumana ho le boima ho amohela kapa hona ho bua ka sethwathwa.

src: you may feel angry, depressed, inadequate and guilty, but you can overcome these feelings and your anxiety by educating yourself about the condition.
tgt: o ka ikgalefela, wa tetebela maikutlo, wa ikgalala mme wa ba wa ipona molato, leha ho le jwalo, o ka kgona ho hlola maikutlo ana kaofela esitana le lona letswalo ka ho ithuta ka maemo ana.

src: epilepsy is the tendency to have recurrent seizures, which occur when there is an abnormal electrical discharge in the brain.
tgt: sethwathwa ke ho akgeha, e leng ntho e etsahalang ha ho ba le maemo a sa tlwaelehang a hlabang jwalo ka mahlasedi a motlakase bokong.

src: why my child?
tgt: hobaneng ngwana ka?

src: understanding epilepsy and why seizures occur doesn’t explain why this happened to your child.
tgt: ho utlwisisa sethwathwa, le hore hobaneng se etsahala, ho ke ke ha hlalosa hobaneng sena se etsahala ngwaneng wa haodiketsahalong tse ka bang tse 66 ho tse lekgolo, sesosa sa sethwathwa ha se tsejwe.

src: this is referred to as idiopathic epilepsy.
tgt: sena he se bitswa idiopathic epilepsy.

src: in the remaining cases the underlying causes can be identified, which is known as symptomatic epilepsy.
tgt: diketsahalong tsena tse 34 tse setseng ho tse lekgolo, sesosa se ka tsebisahala mme sena he sona se bitswa symptomatic epilepsy.

src: there can be a variety of underlying causes such as a head injury, that can occur at any age; a birth injury, such as a lack of oxygen during birth; fever convulsions, encephalitis, meningitis or childhood measles; and metabolic or biochemical disturbances or imbalances.
tgt: ho na le disosa tse fapafapaneng tse kang ho lemala hloohong tse ka etsahalang dilemong leha e le dife tsa bophelo ba motho, ho lemala ha o belehwa, jwalo ka ho haellwa ke ho hema ha o belehwa; ho hatellwa ke feberu, ho ruruha bokong, ho ruruha ha lera le kwahetseng boko, mmokonyane esitana le ho phatsamiseha ha ho sebetsa ka nepo ha masole a mmele.

src: a doctor will prescribe medication based on the age, physical condition and type of seizures your child has.
tgt: ngaka e tla o ngolla meriana o ka e sebedisang ho latela dilemo tsa ngwana hao, maemo a hae a mmele le mofuta wa sethwathwa se mo tshwereng.

src: remember, anticonvulsant medication does not cure epilepsy but, in most cases, will reduce the frequency and severity of seizures.
tgt: hopola, meriana ena e kokobetsang ha e alafe sethwathwa, empa hangata, e fokotsa sekgahla le makgetlo ao sethwathwa se hlaselang ka ona.

src: some tips on parenting a child with epilepsy: make your child aware of the condition.
tgt: dikeletso mabapi le ho hodisa ngwana ya nang le bohloko ba sethwathwa: elellwisa ngwana hao ka maemo a hae.

src: children as young as three can understand that the brain controls the body.
tgt: ho tloha ba le dilemo di tharo feela, bana ba ka utlwisisa hore boko bo laola mmele.

src: older children should be given a more comprehensive explanation.
tgt: ba seng ba holahodile bona ba ka fumantshwa tlhalosetso e phethahetseng.

src: inform close relatives and your child’s friends, teachers and other responsible school officials.
tgt: tsebisa ba leloko le metswalle ya ngwana, matitjhere le ba ikarabellang ka yena sekolong ka maemo a hae.

src: ensure your child receives a comprehensive medical assessment by a qualified professional, ideally a neurologist.
tgt: netefatsa hore ngwana hao o fumana tlhahlobo e phethahetseng ya bongaka ho tswa mothong ya rupelletsweng, ho ka ba molemo ha e ka ba ngaka ya boko le methapokutlo.

src: emphasise your child’s abilities and any activity that will improve their selfacceptance, selfworth and selfconfidence.
tgt: kgothaletsa taba ya hore ngwana hao o sebedisa bokgoni ba hae le ho etsa dintho tse tla ntlafatsa boitshepo ba hae, ho ikamohela le hona ho amohela maemo a hae.

src: ensure adult supervision for some activities, such as swimming.
tgt: netefatsa hore ho ba le motho e moholo ya mo lebeletseng ha a etsa dintho tse kang ho sesa.

src: ensure medication is administered and taken reg ularly as prescribed.
tgt: netefatsa hore o nwa meriana ya hae ho latela ditaelo tsa ngaka.

src: provide a set routine with plenty of rest, three balanced meals per day and regular exercise.
tgt: mo ralle lenaneotshebetso le kenyeletsang, ho robala ka ho lekaneng, ho ja ka nepo hararo ka letsatsi esitana le ho ikwetlisa kgafetsa.

src: when explaining seizures use words that your child will understand.
tgt: ha o hlalosetsa ngwana hao ka sethwathwa, sebedisa mantswe a tla a utlwisisa.

src: an honour to lead the african union vukuzenzele unnamed south africa’s term as chair of the african union has come to an end.
tgt: ke tlotla hore re ile ra fuwa monyetla wa ho etella pele mokgatlo wa dinaha tsa afrika (au) vukuzenzele unnamed sehla sa afrika bo rwa sa ho ba moe tapele wa au se fi hlile pheletsong.

src: as we reflect on our year in this position, i am reminded of the old saying that ‘in crisis lies opportunity’.
tgt: ha re hetla morao moo selemo sa rona se qadileng teng re le maemong ana, ke hopola mantswe a kgale a reng ‘ka hara bobe bo bong le bo bong ho na le botle’.

src: ours was a baptism of fire, having assumed the chairship in the same month the first case of coronavirus was reported on the continent.
tgt: rona re bile le kolobetso ya mollo, jwalo ka ha re bile badulasetulo ka kgwedi e ho bileng le tlaleho ya pele ya motho a nang le kokwanahloko ya corona ka hara kontinente.

src: the priorities we outlined for our term, among them furthering peace and security, the economic empowerment of women and deepening economic integration, had to be immediately and dramatically reoriented to deal with the pandemic.
tgt: maano ao re neng re a beile ka pele sehleng sa rona, a a kgang ntshetsopele ya kgotso le tshireletso, matlafatso ya basadi moruong le ho tebisa ho kopana ha moruo, a ile a tlameha ho phephethwa hanghang ho sa lebellwa, hore fela ho tsebe ho mekamekanwa le sewa sena.

src: our most pressing task was to steer the focus of the african union to addressing the worst global emergency in over a century.
tgt: mosebetsi o neng o re peteditse haholo e bile wa ho tsepamisa maikutlo a au ho phumano ya tharollo ya koduwa ena e mpehadi ka ho fetisisa lefatshe ka bophara dilemong tse fetang tse le kgolo tse fetileng.

src: covid19 has affected all the countries on the continent.
tgt: covid19 e amme dinaha tsohle kontinenteng.

src: to date there are more than 3.5 million confirmed cases in africa, and more than 88,000 people have died.
tgt: ho fihlela hajwale, ho na le batho ba dimiliyone tse tharo le halofo ba ho tsejwang hore ba na le covid19 ka hara afrika, mme ba fetang 88 000 ba hlokahetse.

src: it has been a health, humanitarian, social and economic crisis for african countries, most of whom are inadequately resourced to manage a health emergency of this size.
tgt: e bile bothata bo boholo ditheong tsa bophelo, botho, phedisano le moruo bakeng sa dinaha tsa afrika, tseo bongata ba tsona di hae llwang ke disebediswa tsa ho laola koduwa ya bophelo e kgolo ha kana.

src: and yet, as unprecedented as the nature of the pandemic has been, so too has been the manner in which african countries have come together to fight it.
tgt: le ha e le mona sewa sena se bile seholo ha kana, ho bile jwalo fela le ka mokgwa oo dinaha tsa afrika di ileng tsa ipopa ngatana nngwe twantshong ya sona ka teng.

src: in doing so we have drawn principally on the continent’s own expertise, capabilities and institutions such as the africa centres for disease control and prevention (africa cdc).
tgt: ka ho etsa seo, haholoholo re tshepetse tsebong, bokgo ning le ditheong tsa konti nente tse jwalo ka ditheo tsa afrika tsa taolo le thibelo ya mahloko (africa cdc).

src: africa did not sit by passively as the true extent and danger of the pandemic unfurled.
tgt: afrika ha e a ka ya iketla ya phutha matsoho ya shebella ha sewa sena se kotsi se ntse se nama.

src: from the earliest days of the pandemic and led by the au, we swiftly developed a continental response strategy, driven by the africa cdc and regional task forces.
tgt: ho tloha qalong ya sewa sena re ntse re etelletswe pele ke au, re ile ra etsa leano la ho se phallela ka potlako ka thuso ya africa cdc mmoho le dihlopha tsa tshebetso tsa mabatowa a kontinente.

src: we realised that every country on the continent would be severely affected by the pandemic.
tgt: re ile ra elellwa hore naha enngwe le enngwe kontinenteng e tlo angwa hampe ke sewa sena.

src: most would not have the resources needed to meet the public health challenge or to protect their economies.
tgt: bongata ba tsona di ne di ke ke tsa ba le disebediswa tse hlokahalang bakeng sa ho rarolla mathata a bophelo a setjhaba kapa ho tshireletsa meruo ya tsona.

src: we therefore agreed as african countries to appoint several prominent africans as special envoys, who would engage with international funders and multilateral institutions to make the case for financial support and debt relief on africa’s behalf.
tgt: ka hoo, jwalo ka dinaha tsa afrika re dumellane ho kgetha maaforika a hlaheletseng ka mahetla jwalo ka baemedi ba kgethehileng, ba tla bua le batshehetsi ba tjhelete ba matjhabatjhaba le ditheo tsa dipuso tse fapaneng bakeng sa ho tshehetsa ka tjhelete le kimollo ya mekitlane ya afrika.

src: in this way, working as a one continent, we were able to achieve debt relief for many countries and financial assistance towards our covid response and economic recovery.
tgt: ka mokgwa ona wa ho sebetsa mmoho jwalo ka kontinente, re kgonne ho fihlella kimollo ya mekitlane bakeng sa dinaha tse ngata le ho fumana thuso ya tjhelete bakeng sa ho lwantsha covid19 le ho thusa ho tsosa moruo.

src: but much as african countries went to the international community for support, we first helped ourselves – establishing and capitalising a continental covid19 response fund.
tgt: empa le ha e le mona dinaha tsa afrika di kopile thuso ho matjhabatjhaba, re ithusitse ka borona pele – ra aha latlole la ho lwantsha covid19 a kontinente.

src: for every partnership forged with betterresourced nations and the international donor community, we set up our own innovative and groundbreaking african medical supplies platform to enable all african countries to quickly secure personal protective equipment and other medical supplies in an equitable, affordable manner.
tgt: ka lebaka la tshebedisano mmoho enngwe le enngwe e etswang le dinaha tse nang le disebediswa tse betere mmoho le batshehetsi ba dinaha tsa matjhabatjhaba, re sibollotse motjha wa afrika wa phepelo ya disebediswa le meriana o tswetseng pele, bakeng sa ho thusa dinaha tsohle tsa afrika ho fumana disebediswa tsa tshireletso le phepelo ya meriana ka ho tshwana le ka ditjeho tse tlase.

src: and now that the covid19 vaccine is available, we have worked as a collective to ensure that the continent gets its fair share, working with the covax facility and led by our own african vaccine acquisition task team.
tgt: mme jwalo ka ha ente e thibelang covid19 e se e le teng, re sebeditse mmoho ho netefatsa hore kontinente e fumana karolo ya yona e e tshwanetseng, ka tshebedisano mmoho le setheo sa covax le ketello pele ya sehlopha sa afrika sa tshebetso ya phumano ya ente.

src: vaccine rollout has already commenced on the continent and we aspire to have the majority of the continent’s population vaccinated by the end of 2021 to achieve herd immunity.
tgt: ente e se e qadile ho fihla ka hara kontinente mme re labalabela ho bona boholo ba batho ba kontinente ba entile mafelong a 2021, hore re fihlelle setjhaba se sengata se entileng se seng se sa tshwaetsehe.

src: we have acted as one to protect health, people and livelihoods on the continent.
tgt: re sebeditse mmoho bake ng sa ho tshireletsa bophelo, batho le tshehetso ya bophe lo kontinenteng.

src: in doing so, we have demonstrated our capacity for selfreliance and our ability to be the drivers of our own development.
tgt: ka ho etsa jwalo, re bontshitse bokgoni ba ho ikemela le ho intshetsa pele.

src: despite the dominance of covid19, we have still managed to make advances in several of our key priorities.
tgt: le ha e le mona covid19 e re hlwele setha, re ntse re kgonne ho ntshetsa pele maano a rona a mmalwa a ka sehlohong.

src: during our term, the africa continental free trade area (afcfta) was finally launched, heralding a new era of intraafrican trade and economic integration.
tgt: sehleng sa rona ho ile ha sibollwa letsholo la kgwebisano ya dinaha tsa konti nente ya afrika ntle le dite fello (afcfta), e bontshang nako e ntjha kgwebisanong ya dinaha tsa afrika le kopanelong ya moruo.

src: even under the difficult conditions posed by the pandemic, the continent has pushed ahead with towards the goal of ‘silencing the guns’ on the continent.
tgt: le maemong a thata a tlisitsweng ke sewa sena, kontinente e ntse e kgonne ho tswela pele ka leano la ho ‘kgutsisa dithunya’ ka hara kontinente.

src: the au has been actively involved in negotiations around the grand ethiopian renaissance dam, in achieving a ceasefire in libya and promoting peace in south sudan.
tgt: au e ile ya nka karolo dipuisanong tsa grand ethiopian renai ssance dam mme ya fihlella ho kgutsisa dithunya libya le ho tlisa kgotso naheng ya south sudan.

src: another focus of our term has been on the economic empowerment of women, which we will continue to champion even beyond our term and throughout the decade of african women’s financial and economic inclusion to 2030. as we hand over the baton to the democratic republic of congo (drc) we leave this preeminent continental body in a position of greater strength.
tgt: nqa enngwe eo re neng re tsepamisitse maikutlo ho yona sehleng sa rona ke ho matlafatso ya basadi moruong, eo re tla tswela pele ho e kenya tshebetsong le ka mora sehla sa rona le nakong ya dilemo tse leshome tsa kenyeletso ya basadi ba afrika ditjheleteng le moruong ho leba ho 2030. jwalo ka ha re fetisetsa boetapele ho naha ya democratic republic of congo (drc), re tlohela ketapele ena e kgabane ya kontinente e le maemong a matle ho feta pele.

src: south africa will continue to play its part to foster integration on the continent, and support the incoming chair and the organisation in its efforts to meet the aspirations of the au’s agenda 2063. when the organisation for african unity was founded in 1963, member states planted the seeds of cooperation and solidarity in pursuit of a better life for all the peoples of africa.
tgt: afrika borwa e tla tswela pele ho nka karolo ho tlisa kopano ka hara kontinente, le ho tshehetsa ketapele e ntjha le matsapa a au a ho phethahatsa ditabatabelo tsa ona tsa agenda 2063. ha mokgatlo wa dinaha tsa afrika o ne o thewa ka 1963, dinaha tseo e leng ditho mokgatlong ona di ile tsa jala peo ya tshebedisano mmoho le bonngwe ntshetsopeleng ya bophelo bo botle bakeng sa batho bohle ba afrika.

src: they affirmed that african unity was paramount if the welfare and wellbeing of africa’s people was to be assured.
tgt: di ile tsa bolela hore kopano ya afrika e bohlokwa haholo bakeng sa ho netefatsa the kolohelo le bophelo bo botle ba maafrika.

src: history bears witness that these seeds have not always fallen on fertile ground, and over the years the continental unity project has experienced many hurdles and false starts.
tgt: nalane e paka hore ha se ka mehla moo peo ena e ileng ya wela mobung o nonneng, mme dilemong tse ngata tse fetileng, porojeke ya kopano ya kontinente e bone ditshita tse ngata le qalo tse fosahe tseng.

src: covid19 vaccine: what you need to know allison cooper with south afri ca’s mass coro navirus disease (covid19) vaccination programme rolling out for healthcare workers in february, vuk’uzenzele sheds some light on what the covid19 vaccine is, how it works and why it’s so important to stop the spread of the virus.
tgt: se o hlokang ho se tseba ka ente ya covid19 allison cooper jwalo ka ha afrika bo rwa e tlo etsa lenane la ho enta matshwele tshwele a basebetsi ba bo phelo bakeng sa covid19 ka hlakola, vuk’uzenzele e hlalosa hore ente ya covid19 ke eng, mme hobaneng e le bohlokwa bakeng sa ho thibela ho nama ha kokwanahloko.

src: what does a vaccine do?
tgt: ente e etsang?

src: a vaccine trains your body’s immune system (which fights infection), to produce antibodies (proteins that fight disease) – exactly like it would if you were exposed to a virus.
tgt: ente e etsa hore masole a hao a mmele (a lwantshang tshwaetso) a hlahise dithi bela mahloko (diporotheine tse lwantshang mahloko) – ka tsela e tshwanang hantle le ha o na le tshwaetso ya kokwanahloko.

src: why is the vaccine so important?
tgt: hobaneng ha ente e le bohlokwa tje?

src: being vaccinated against covid19 is an effective way to protect yourself against the virus because your risk of infection is reduced.
tgt: ho entela covid19 ke mo kgwa o motle wa ho itshire letsa kgahlano le kokwana hloko, hobane kotsi ya hore o tswaetsehe e a fokotseha.

src: you are then less likely to pass the virus on to someone else.
tgt: ka hoo, ha ho bobebe hore o ka tshwaetsa batho ba bang ka kokwanahloko.

src: the aim of vaccination is to reach herd immunity – when enough of the population is immune to the virus it provides indirect protection to those who aren’t immune, bringing the spread of the virus under control.
tgt: sepheo sa ho enta ke ho fihlella palo e hodimo ya setjhaba se sa tshwaetseheng – ha palo e lekaneng ya batho e tshireletsehile ho kokwanahloko, batho ba sa entang le bona ba a tshireletseha, mme ho nama ha kokwa nahloko ho a laoleha.

src: are vaccines necessary to prevent the spread of covid19?
tgt: na ebe ente e bohlokwa bakeng sa ho thibela ho nama ha covid19?

src: there is overwhelming scientific evidence that vaccination is the best defence against serious infections.
tgt: ho na le bopaki bo bongata ba saense bo pakang hore ho enta ke mokgwa o motle wa ho thibela ditshwaetso tse kotsi thata.

src: will the vaccine stop me from getting covid19?
tgt: na ebe ente e tla ntshireletsa hore ke se fumane tshwaetso ya covid19?

src: no vaccine provides 100% protection.
tgt: ha ho ente e fanang ka tshire letso e 100%.

src: herd immunity also does not provide full protection to those who are not vaccinated.
tgt: palo e hodimo ya setjhaba se entileng ha e tshireletse ba sa entang ka botlalo.

src: however, with herd immunity, these people will have substantial protection.
tgt: le ha ho le jwalo, ka palo e hodimo ya setjhaba se entileng, batho bana ba sa entang, bongata ba bona bo ka tshireletseha.

src: is the vaccination safe?
tgt: na ebe ente e boloke hile?

src: covid19 vaccines go through a demanding, multistage testing process, including large trials that involve tens of thousands of people.
tgt: diente tsa covid19 di feta mekgahlelong e thata, e me ngata ya diteko tse kgolo, tse akgang diteko tse etswang ho mashomeshome a dikete tsa batho.

src: every vaccine used in south africa’s mass vaccination programme has to be approved by the south african health products regulatory authority.
tgt: ente enngwe le enngwe e tlo sebediswa ho matshweletshwele a afrika borwa e tlameha ho dumellwa ke lekgotla la afrika borwa la taolo ya dihlahiswa tsa bophelo (sahpra).

src: the oxford universityastrazeneca vaccine has already been approved by various regulators around the world and is being rolled out in other countries.
tgt: ente e bitswang oxford universityastrazeneca e se e dumelletswe ke balaodi ba fapaneng lefatshe ka bophara mme e se e sebediswa dinaheng tse ding.

src: who will get the vaccine first?
tgt: ebe afrika borwa e fumana ente ya yona ya pele hotswa kae?

src: the country’s estimated 1.25 million healthcare workers will receive the vaccine first.
tgt: dihlopha tse pedi tsa diente tse tlo fihla afrika borwa (tse miliyone ka phere kgong le halofo ya miliyone ka hlakola) ke tsa oxford universityastrazeneca e tswang setheong se bitswang serum institute of india.

src: in phase two, essential workers such as teachers, police, municipal workers, taxi drivers and other frontline personnel; people in institutions such as old age homes, shelters and prisons; and people over 60 and adults with comorbidities will be prioritised.
tgt: mokgahlelong wa bobedi ho tla entwa basebetsi ba ditshebeletso tse ka sehlohlolong pele, jwalo ka baruta bana, maponesa, basebetsi ba masepala, bakganni ba ditekesi le basebetsi ba bang ba ka sehlohlolong; batho ba ditheong tse jwalo ka mahae a maqheku, dithekolohelong le ditjhankaneng; le batho ba dilemo tse ka hodimo ho 60 le batho ba baholo ba phelang le mahloko a sa phekoleheng.

src: in phase three, about 22.5 million of the remaining adult population will be vaccinated.
tgt: mokgahlelong wa boraro ho tlo entwa batho ba baholo ba setseng ba ka bang dimiliyone tse 22.5. sepheo ke ho enta batho ba 67% ha selemo sa 2021 se fela.

src: the target is to vaccinate 67% of the population by the end of 2021. by then we should reach herd immunity.
tgt: re tshwanetse re be re se re fihlelletse palo e hodimo ya setjhaba se entuweng ka nako eo.

src: who is purchasing the vaccine?
tgt: ebe ke mang a rekang ente?

src: government is the sole pur chaser of vaccines and will distribute them to provincial governments and the private sector.
tgt: mmuso ke ona o le mong fela o dumelletsweng ho reka ente mme o tla e isa mmusong wa porofense le mafapheng a poraefete.

src: steps to revive the economy vukuzenzele unnamed it will soon be a year since the first reported case of coronavirus disease (covid19) in our country.
tgt: mehato ya ho tsosolosa moruo vukuzenzele unnamed e se e tla ba selemo jwale re bile le ke tsahalo ya pele ya kokwanahloko ya khorona e ileng ya tlalehwa naheng ya rona.

src: the pandemic has come at a great cost to both public health and the livelihoods of millions of our people.
tgt: sewa sena se bakile ditshenyehelo tse kgolo bophelong ba setjhaba esita le maphelong a dimilione tsa batho ba habo rona.

src: many workers lost part of their income as their work hours were reduced with many being retrenched.
tgt: basebetsi ba bangata ba lahlehetswe ke karolo ya meputso ya bona ha dihora tsa bona tsa tshebetso di fokotswa, mme ba bangata ba fokotswa mesebetsing.

src: several businesses have incurred heavy losses from scaledback operations.
tgt: dikgwebo tse ngata di bile le tahlehelo e boima ka lebaka la ditshebetso tse fokoditsweng.

src: others have had to close.
tgt: tse ding di ile tsa tlameha ho kwalwa.

src: people working in the informal sector have also suffered.
tgt: batho ba sebetsang karolong ya moruo e sa hlophiswang le bona ba amehile habohloko.

src: most difficult of all, the pandemic has claimed the lives of breadwinners in many families, leaving them destitute and fearful for the future.
tgt: ntlheng e boima ka ho fetisisa, sewa sena se nkile maphelo a bafepi malapeng a mangata, mme ba malapa ba sala ba itlhophere, hape ba tsielehille bakeng sa bokamoso.

src: this is why the extensive relief measures we put in place were both necessary and urgent.
tgt: ke ka lebaka lena mehato e pharaletseng ya diphallelo eo re e nkileng e neng e hlokeha e bile e le e potlakileng.

src: and, now that nearly a year has passed, we can say that these measures have proved effective.
tgt: hape, jwalo ka ha ho batla ho fetile selemo, re ka re mehato ena e atlehile.

src: of the full package of relief measures that we introduced, perhaps the two measures that had the greatest impact were the special covid19 social relief of distress grant and the unemployment insurance fund's (uif) covid19 temporary employer/employee relief scheme, generally known as covid ters.
tgt: kakaretsong ya yona mehato ena ya diphallelo tseo re di entseng mohlomong e mmedi e bileng le tshusumetso e matla haholo ke phallelo ya setjhaba e ikgethileng ya covid19 le ya uif, ya leano la diphallelo tsa basebetsi la nakwana, le tsejwang feela e le covid ters.

src: we would not have been able to roll out these measures in such a short space of time if we had not had an extensive social security infrastructure already in place.
tgt: re ne re ke ke ra atleha ho qala mehato ena ka nako e kgutshwane hakana haeba re ne re se na dibopeho tsa motheo tsa tshireletseho ya setjhaba tse pharaletseng tse neng di se di sebetsa.

src: we were able to respond to this huge and immediate need in our society thanks to the substantial nationwide infrastructure and systems of the south african social security agency and the uif.
tgt: re ile ra kgona ho arabela tlhoko ena e kgolo e bileng e le e potlakileng setjhabeng sa rona, re leboha dibopeho tsa motheo tse kgolo naheng ka bophara le ditsamaiso tsa setsi sa afrika borwa sa tshireletso ya botjhaba (sassa) le letlole la inshorense ya batho ba feletsweng ke mosebetsi (uif).

src: there were certainly technical and other glitches along the way, but most of these were speedily resolved.
tgt: kantle ho qeaqeo, a bile teng mathatanyana a setekgeniki le a mang boleleng ba nako, empa tsena tsohle di ile tsa rarolleha kapele.

src: these government agencies did outstanding work to enroll millions of new beneficiaries and ensure they were paid.
tgt: diagente tsena tsa mmuso di entse mosebetsi o babatsehang wa ho ngodisa dimilione tsa baamohedi ba batjha le ho netefatsa ho lefuwa ha bona.

src: the support provided by the uif was a lifeline to struggling businesses and employees.
tgt: tshehetso e fanweng ke uif e inotse dikgwebo tse thekeselang esita le basebetsi.

src: it made the difference between companies remaining open and being forced to close, between jobs saved and jobs lost.
tgt: e entse phapang pakeng tsa dikhampani tse setseng di sebetsa le tse ileng tsa tlameha ho kwalwa, pakeng tsa mesebetsi e ileng ya bolokeha le e ileng ya lahleha.

src: this benefited businesses like sihle’s brew, a restaurant in gauteng, which was able to retain its 18 employees because of the ters scheme.
tgt: sena se ile sa tswela molemo dikgwebo tse jwalo ka sihle’s brew, kgwebo ya dijo gauteng, e ileng ya kgona ho boloka basebetsi ba yona ba 18 ka lebaka la morero wa ters.

src: thanks to government support, mamoshal agae trading and projects, an autoelectrical business in mokopane, was able to pay its workers as well as its rent and rates during the lockdown.
tgt: re leboha tshehetso ya mmuso, mamoshalagae trading and pojects, kgwebo ya motlakase wa dipalangwang mokopane, e ile ya kgona ho lefa basebetsi ba yona esita le ho lefella rente, le ditefiso tsa thepa nakong ya ho kginwa ha tshebetso le maeto.

src: employees in dire straits were able to receive a portion of their salaries.
tgt: basebetsi ba maqakabetsing ba ile ba kgona ho amohela karolo ya meputso ya bona.

src: lindiwe ntuli, a paralegal in centurion, has told how receiving her benefits enabled her to work from home and be able to afford her rent.
tgt: lindiwe ntuli, molaodi wa molao, centurion, o boletse kamoo ho fumana ha hae meropotso ho ileng ha mo thusa hore a tsebe ho sebeletsa hae mme a kgonane le rente ya hae.

src: there are many stories of companies that have been able to stay afloat over the past year because of the support they received from the uif.
tgt: di ngata dipale tsa dikhampani tse ileng tsa qoba ho teba nakong ya selemo sena se fetileng ka lebaka la tshehetso eo di e fumaneng ho uif.

src: the same can be said of the small businesses helped by the various grants and loans provided by a number of departments.
tgt: ho ka phetwa tse tshwanang le dikgwebong tse nyenyane tse thusitsweng ke diphallelo tse fapafapaneng esita le dikadimo tse fanweng ke mafapha a mangata.

src: these measures greatly helped our people in their time of need.
tgt: mehato ena e thusitse batho ba habo rona haholo nakong ya bona ya tlhoko.

src: as we transition from relief to recovery, we have to shift gear.
tgt: jwalo ka ha re fetoha ho tloha ho diphallelo ho ya ho tsosoloso, re tlameha ho fetola mokgwa wa rona wa tshebetso.

src: while these relief measures were designed to be temporary, the economy will continue to feel the effects of the pandemic for some time.
tgt: le hoja mehato ena ya kokobetso e ne e raletswe ho ba ya nakwana, moruo o tla tswela pele ho utlwa maoma a sewa sena nako e itseng.

src: even as lockdown restrictions have been eased, many companies are struggling to cope with the fallout of months of diminished operations and lost revenue.
tgt: le ha e le mona dipehelo tsa ho kginwa ha tshebetso le maeto di nyenyisitswe, dikhampani tse ngata di fumana ho le thata ho emelana le ditlamorao tsa dikgwedi tse ngata tsa ditshebetso tse fokotsehileng esita le kuno e lahlehileng.

src: it is for this reason that, following extensive discussion with social partners at the national economic development and labour council the covid ters benefit has been extended until 15 march 2021 for sectors that have not been able to fully operate.
