src: because this foundational learning is key to a child’s success in later years, the basic education laws amendment bill that is currently before parliament proposes that it be compulsory for all children to receive two years of ecd before they enter grade 1. it is at this stage that children should be taught, learn through play and receive at least one meal a day.
tgt: thuto ya motheo e bohlokwa katlehong ya ngwana hamo rao dilemong, ke ka hona bili ya tlhomathiso ya melao ya thuto ya motheo e palame nteng e hlahisa hore ho tlame hore bana bohle ba fumane dilemo tse pedi tsa ecd pele ba kena ho kereiti ya 1. ke mokgahlelong ona moo bana ba lokelang ho rutwa, ho ithuta ka ho bapala le ho fumana bonnyane dijo hang ka letsatsi.

src: early childhood development centres don’t just prepare our country’s youngest citizens to succeed in school; they are also an important source of entrepreneurship and job creation.
tgt: ditsi tsa thuto ya bana ba banyenyane ha di lokisetse baahi ba naha ya rona ba ba nyenyane ho tswella sekolong feela; di boetse di bohlokwa haholo jwaloka mehlodi ya qalo ya dikgwebo le ho thehwa ha mesebetsi.

src: these centres are an important part of the care economy.
tgt: ditsi tsena ke karolo ya bohlokwa ya tsa bohlokomedi.

src: they sustain livelihoods, especially for women, which contributes to job creation in many communities.
tgt: di thusa batho ho iphedisa, haholo holo basadi, e leng ntho e kenyang letsoho ho the hweng ha mesebetsi metseng e mengata.

src: when the covid19 pandemic struck, ecd centres were hard hit.
tgt: ditsi tsa ecd di ile tsa ameha haholo ke ho qhoma ha sewa sa covid19.

src: facilities that rely on school fees to keep running were unable to pay their staff and many parents who lost their jobs were unable to keep their children enrolled.
tgt: dibaka tse lefisang bana hore di nne di sebetse di ile tsa hloleha ho lefa basebetsi ba tsona mme batswadi ba bangata ba neng ba felletswe ke mosebetsi ba hloleha ho boloka bana ba bona ditsing.

src: in response, government established the ecd employment stimulus relief fund to help ecd centres that had lost income as a result of the pandemic and to enable them to recover.
tgt: mmuso o ile wa thusa ka ho theha letlole la ecd la thuso ya ho imolla molemong wa matlafatso ya mosebetsi ho thusa ditsi tsa ecd tse neng di sa kenelwe ke tjhelete ka lebaka la sewa, le ho di thusa ho tsoha.

src: preparing our youngest citizens with the tools they need to succeed in life is a responsibility we must collectively shoulder.
tgt: ho thusa baahi ba rona ba banyenyane ka disebediswa tseo ba di hlokang hore ba tswelle bophelong ke boi karabelo boo re lokelang ho bo jara bohle.

src: we must continue to do all we can, as government, the private sector and development organisations, to support early childhood development.
tgt: re lokela ho tswela pele ho etsa kamoo re ka kgonang, re le mmuso, lekala la poraefete le me kgatlo ya ntshetsopele, ho tshehetsa ditsi tsa thuto ya bana ba banyenyane.

src: with the many valuable services it provides, whether it is educating our children, providing childcare for working parents or creating opportunities for entrepreneurs, ecd makes a huge contribution to the achievement of many of our developmental goals.
tgt: ka ditshebeletso tse ngata tsa bohlokwa tseo ecd e fanang ka tsona, ho kenye letsa thuto ya bana, ho fana ka tlhokomelo ya bana bakeng sa batswadi ba sebetsang kapa ho theha menyetla ya mosebetsi ya ba iqallang di kgwebo, lenaneo lena le na le seabo se seholo phihlellong ya maikemisetso a mangata a rona a ntshetsopele.

src: since the care economy is mainly driven by women, such support goes a long way towards helping women, especially in disadvantaged communities, to become financially secure and independent.
tgt: erekaha tsa bohlokomedi di laolwa ke basadi haholo, tshehetso ena e thusa basadi haholo, haholoholo ba me tseng e itlhophereng, hore ba be le ditjhelete ba ikemele.

src: how to save water more matshediso the reliability of water supply by municipalities to households across south africa is only at 68%, despite the strides made by the department of water and sanitation to eradicate water supply backlogs over the years.
tgt: kamoo metsi a ka bolokwang kateng more matshediso leha lefapha la metsi le bohlweki le entse matsapa a ho lwantsha tshallo morao phepelong ya metsi dilemong tse fetileng, naheng ya afrika borwa malapa ao bomasepala ba kgonang ho a fepela metsi a ballwa ho 68% feela.

src: water and sanitation deputy minister david mahlobo says this is due to old infrastructure, lack of operation and maintenance on water schemes, and the poor integration between housing programmes and current infrastructure development projects.
tgt: motlatsaletona la metsi le bohlweki o re sena se bakwa ke meralo ya kgale ya ditshebeletso, tlhokeho ya tshebediso le tlhokomelo ya meralo ya metsi, le momahano e sa tiyang ya mananeo a phumantsho ya bodulo le diprojeke tsa jwale tsa ntshetsopele ya meralo ya ditshebeletso.

src: "it is a major concern that the provision of reliable supply water is showing signs of decline," he says.
tgt: "ho ngongorehisa haholo ho bona ho se ho se tshepo phepelong ya metsi mme dintho di senyeha " ho boletse yena.

src: as a water scarce country, south africa ranks among 30 driest countries in the world.
tgt: afrika borwa ke naha e haellwang ke metsi, mme e hara dinaha tse 30 tse fokollwang ke metsi lefatsheng.

src: most of the country’s water comes from rainfall, but with the recorded average rainfall that is 40% less than the annual world average, the country is often affected by drought.
tgt: bongata ba metsi a naha ena bo tswa puleng, empa naha e dula e angwa ke komello ka lebaka la pula e seng kae e nang e lekanyetswang tlasa 40% ha e bapiswa le e nang dinaheng tse ding lefatsheng selemo le selemo.

src: however, the department has water saving tips for you.
tgt: leha ho le jwalo lefapha le o fa dikeletso tsa ho boloka metsi.

src: saving water in your home or business turn the tap off¬ between washing your face, brushing your teeth or shaving.
tgt: ho boloka metsi lapeng kapa kgwebong kwala pompo pakeng tsa ho hlapa sefahleho, ho tsukunya kapa ho kuta ditedu.

src: taking a fiveminute shower a day instead of a bath will use a third of the water used bathing in a bath tub, saving up to 400 litres a week.
tgt: ho hlapa ka shawareng metsotso e mehlano ka letsatsi ho e na le ho hlapela bateng ho foko tsa tshebediso ya metsi a mangata, mme sena se boloka dilitara tse 400 ka beke.

src: showering can use up to 20 litres of water per minute, whereas taking a bath can use between 80 and 150 litres of water per bath.
tgt: shawara e sebedisa di litara tse 20 ka motsotso, ha bate e nka dilitara tse pakeng tsa tse 80 ho ya ho tse 150 bakeng sa motho ka mong.

src: if you prefer to bath, do not fill up the bathtub.
tgt: ebang o kgetha ho tola ka bateng, se ka e tlatsa.

src: avoid flushing the toilet unnecessarily.
tgt: qoba ho otla metsi ntlwaneng ho sa hlokehe.

src: dispose of tissues, insects and other waste in the trash rather than the toilet.
tgt: lahla dithishu, dikokwana le matlakala a mang moqomong eseng ka thoeletheng.

src: every time you flush the toilet, 12 litres of water is used.
tgt: nako le nako ha o otla metsi ho sebetsa dilitara tse 12 tsa metsi.

src: fix a leaking toilet otherwise it can waste up to 100 000 litres of water in one year.
tgt: lokisa thoelethe e du tlang, ntle le moo e senya dilitara tse 100 000 tsa metsi ka selemo.

src: use "grey water" — used water from baths, washing machines and other safe sources to flush your toilet.
tgt: sebedisa "metsi a sebedisitsweng — a neng a hlapa bateng, a tswang metjhining ya ho hlatswa diaparo le mehloding e meng e bolokehileng ho otla thoelethe ya hao.

src: kettles should not be filled to the brim but with just enough water for your needs.
tgt: diketlele di se ke tsa tlatswa ho feta tekano empa di tshelwe metsi a lekaneng ditlhoko tsa hao.

src: this will reduce your electricity bill too.
tgt: sena se fokotsa le ditjeho tsa motlakase.

src: use a bucket rather than a hose to wash your car.
tgt: sebedisa metsi a emereng eseng paepe ya metsi ha o hlatswa koloi ya hao.

src: if you have to use a hose, use a sprayer that can be turned off¬ inbetween spraying the car.
tgt: ebang o sebedisa paepe, e be e fafatsang e ka kwalwang le ho bulwa kgafe tsa ha ho fafatswa koloi ka metsi.

src: using a garden hose could use as much as 30 litres of water per minute.
tgt: paepe ya sera peng e sebedisa dilitara tse ballwang ho 30 tsa metsi ka motsotso.

src: farmers must ensure that they keep toxic insecticides away from water sources and streams.
tgt: balemi ba lokela ho netefatsa hore meriana e bolayang dikokwana e nang le tjhefu ha e kene mehloding ya metsi le melapong.

src: people living in rural areas should be careful not to use the river or riverbank as a toilet.
tgt: batho ba lokela ho ela hloko ba se tshilafatse dinoka kapa mabopo a dinoka mo ba dulang.

src: prep can prevent hiv allison cooper as south africa comme morates world aids day on 1 december and 16 days of activism against genderbased violence (gbv), from 25 november to 10 december, vuk’uzenzele explores the relationship between gbv and hiv/aids.
tgt: na prep e ka thibela hiv allison cooper jwalo ka ha afri ka borwa e keteka letsatsi la matjhaba la eitsi ka la 1 tshitwe le matsatsi a 16 a twantsho ya tlhekefetso ya basadi (gbvf) ho tloha ka la 25 pudungwana ho isa ka la 10 tshitwe, vuk’uzenzele e lekola dikamano pakeng tsa gbv le hiv/aids.

src: the genderbased vio lence and femicide (gbvf) response fund strives to ensure that south africa is free from gbvf against women; children; and the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer/questioning, asexual and more (lgbtqia+) community.
tgt: letlole la twantsho ya tlhekefetso ya basadi le dipolao tsa bona le netefatsa hore le fedisa ditlhekefetso le dipolao tsa basadi, bana le batho ba ratanang le ba bonng bo tshwanang le ba bona, ba fetolang bonng le ba nang le maikutlo a fetofetohang a bonng le ba bang (lgbtqia+).

src: the fund was launched by president cyril ramaphosa in february 2021, to support the implementation of the national strategic plan on gbvf.
tgt: letlole lena le ne le thehwe ke mopresidente cyril ramaphosa ka hlakola 2021, ka maikemisetso a ho kenya tshebetsong leano la naha la ho lwantsa gbvf.

src: according to the fund’s website, it plays a critical role in making change happen, based on research, awareness and practical support to organisations actively engaged in the fight against gbvf.
tgt: ka ho ya ka websaete ya letlole lena, letlole lena le thusa haholo ho tliseng diphetoho ka lebaka la dipatlisiso, ditlhokomedisa le tshehetso ya lona ho mekgatlo e lwantshanang le gbvf.

src: one of the organisations supported by the fund is the kwazulunatal based gugu dlamini foundation, which received r250 000 from the gbvf in 2022. executive director of the gugu dlamini foundation, mandisa mabaso, established the foundation in 2010 after her mother – the late gugu dlamini – was stoned to death in 1998 in durban for disclosing her hivpositive status.
tgt: o mong wa mekgatlo e fumaneng tshehetso letloleng lena ke wa gugu dlamini wa kwazulunatal o fumaneng r250 000 ho tswa letloleng la twantsho ya gbvf selemong sa 2022. molaodi e moholo wa mokgatlo ona wa gugu dlamini foundation, mandisa mabaso, ke yena ya neng a o thehe ka 2010 ka mora hore mmae – mofu gugu dlamini – a ne a bolawe ka sehloho ka ho pitlwa ka majwe ka 1998 mane thekong ka mora ho bolela hore o na le hiv .

src: "the foundation aims to strengthen local governance to improve the gbvf response, which is essential to achieving hiv epidemic control in south africa," says mabaso.
tgt: "mokgatlo o ikemiseditse ho thusa masepala ho lwantshana le gbvf e leng se hlokahalang ho lwantshana le sewa sa hiv afrika borwa," ho rialo mabaso.

src: "it also aims to reduce hiv/aids infections, increase access to care and improve health outcomes for females and males infected and affected by hiv/aids," she adds.
tgt: "mokgatlo ona o boetse o ikemiseditse ho fokotsa ditshwaetso tsa hiv/aids, ho thusa ho bebofatsa ditsela tsa ho fumana thuso ya tsa bophelo bo botle le ho thusa banna le basadi ba phelang le ba anngweng ke hiv/aids," ke yena hape.

src: the funding that the foundation receives assists 522 255 women and girls and 900 men and boys from families affected by gbv and domestic violence; abused persons living with disabilities; and the lgbtqia+ community, says mabaso.
tgt: tshehetso ena ya tjhelete e thusitse hore re thuse banana le basadi ba 522 255 banna le bashemane ba 900 ba tswang malapeng a anngweng ke gbv mmoho le merusu ya ka lapeng le ditlhekefetso tsa batho ba sa itekanelang le ba lgbtqia+ ho rialo mabaso.

src: according to unaids, in areas of high hiv burden, women who are victims of gbv face up to a 50% higher chance of acquiring hiv .
tgt: ka ho ya ka unaids, basadi ba bangata bao e bang mahlatsipa a gbv , ba ba le menyetla ya persente tse 50 tsa hore ba ka ba le hiv .

src: some of the reasons for this are rape and the refusal by men to use condoms.
tgt: a mang a mabaka ke peto le banna ba sa batleng ho sebedisa dikgohlopo.

src: what is prep?
tgt: prep ke eng?

src: one of the ways to prevent hiv infection is by taking preexposure prophylaxis (prep), which is a medicine taken daily by hivnegative people who are at high risk of being exposed to hiv , through sexual contact or injection drug use.
tgt: e nngwe ya ditsela tsa ho thibela ho tshwaetseha ke hiv ke ya ho nwa moriana o bitswang preexposure prophylaxis (prep), o nowang kamehla ke motho ya se nang hiv , empa ya kotsing ya ho tshwaetseha ka thobalano kapa ka ho sebedisa ente.

src: in august, health minister, dr joe phaahla said that south africa has the highest oral prep initiation in subsahara.
tgt: ka phato, letona joe phaahla o boletse hore afrika borwa e na le palo e hodimo ya batho ba sebedisang prep dinaheng tsena tse haufi le lehwatata la sahara.

src: he said that 70%, or 2 419, of south africa’s public primary healthcare facilities have integrated oral prep into their routine package of services.
tgt: o boletse hore ditsi tsa bophelo bo botle tsa afrika borwa tse etsang persente tse 70 kapa re re tse 2 419 di se di sebedisa prep .

src: "a person on prep does not have to take it for the rest of their lives, they can choose to take it every time they are at risk of being infected with hiv .
tgt: "motho ya sebedisang prep ha a ya tlameha ho e sebedisa bophelo bohle ba hae, o na le boikgethelo ba ho e sebedisa ha motho a bona hore o kotsing ya ho tshwaetswa ke hiv .

src: however, for prep to be effective, it must be taken every day [during this time]," confirms mabaso.
tgt: leha ho le jwalo, hore prep e sebetse hantle, e tlameha ho nowa kamehla [nakong eo]," ho bolela mabaso.

src: it should also be used with other protective methods, such as female and male condoms, because prep does not protect a person against other sexually transmitted infections and it is not a contraceptive.
tgt: e tlameha ho sebediswa le mekgwa e meng ya tshireletso e kang kgohlopo ya basadi kapa ya banna hobane prep ha e o sireletse kgahlano le mahloko a mang a tsa thobalano, hape ha e thibele pelehi.

src: mabaso says that in cases where a couple wants to have a baby, prep can assist to prevent hiv infection of the hivnegative partner and the unborn baby.
tgt: mabaso o re prep e ka thusa nakong eo baratani ba batlang ho ba le ngwana hore molekane ya se nang hiv a se tshwaetsehe ha mmoho le lesea la bona.

src: meanwhile, earlier this year, the south african health products regulatory authority approved the use of a vaginal ring as a prep .
tgt: ho sa le jwalo, mathwasong a selemo sena, mokgatlo wa afrika borwa o laolang meriana o tjhaetse monwana tshebediso ya sesebediswa se bitswang vaginal ring jwalo ka prep .

src: the ring contains an antiretroviral drug called dapivirine and must be changed every month.
tgt: sesebediswa sena se na le moriana o lwantshang hiv o bitswang dapivirine mme se tlameha ho tjhentjhwa jwalo ka kgwedi.

src: in addition, a new prep – an injection that lasts for two months – is awaiting approval.
tgt: ho feta moo, ho na le mofuta o motjha wa prep – eo e leng ente mme yona e dula nako e ka etsang dikgwedi tse pedi mading – mme le yona e emetse ho tjhaelwa monwana.

src: once approved, people will no longer have to remember to take a pill each day.
tgt: ha e se e tjhaetswe monwana, batho jwale ba ke ke ba sa tlameha ho nna ba nwa dipidisi kamehla.

src: safe sex the foundation also aims to reduce hiv infections by promoting the use of condoms and safe sex.
tgt: thobalano e bolokehilengmokgatlo ona o ikemiseditse ho fokotsa ditshwaetso tsa hiv ka ho kgothaletsa batho ho etsa thobalano e bolokehileng esitana le ho sebedisa dikgohlopo.

src: "we urge children and youth to delay engaging in sexual intercourse until they are ready to make more informed and healthier choices," says mabaso.
tgt: "re ipiletsa ho bana le batjha hore ba se phakise ho kena ho tsa thobalano ho fihlela ba kgona ho etsa diqeto tse nepahetseng," ho rialo mabaso.

src: "we also promote safer sex by emphasising condom use and only having one partner at a time.
tgt: "re boetse re kgothaletsa le thobalano e bolokehileng ka ho kgothaletsa tshebediso ya kgohlopo le ho ba le molekane a le mong.

src: what hiv positive breastfeeding moms should know vukuzenzele unnamed with south africa observing world aids day on the 1st of december, the kwazulunatal department of health has advised hiv positive mothers to consider breastfeeding their babies exclusively for six months.
tgt: seo batswetse ba phelang le hiv ba tlamehang ho se tseba vukuzenzele unnamed e tswella pele ho tswa ho leqephe la 1jwalo ka ha afrika borwa e keteka letsatsi la matjhaba la eitsi ka la 1 tshitwe, lefapha la bophelo la kwazulunatal le ele tsa bomme ba phelang le hiv hore ba nya ntshe masea a bona letswele feela dikgwedi tse tsheletseng.

src: according to the depart ment, if you are an hiv positive breastfeeding mother, it is important to discuss feeding choices with your hiv counsellor.
tgt: ho ya ka lefapha, haeba o phela le hiv , empa o batla ho nyantsha, ho bohlokwa ho buisana le moeletsi ka ditaba tsa hiv .

src: if you choose to breast feed, be sure to breastfeed exclusively for the first six months.
tgt: haeba o kgetha ho nyantsha lesea la hao, le nyantshe letswele feela dikgwedi tse tsheletseng tsa pele.

src: research has shown that the baby has very little chance of getting hiv from breastmilk if the mother exclusively breastfeeds.
tgt: dipatlisiso di bontsha hore menyetla e menyane ya hore lesea le tshwaetswe ke hiv haeba motswetse a le nyantsha letswele feela.

src: during the months that you are pregnant, and breastfeeding, be sure to use a condom during sexual intercourse to prevent any new infection.
tgt: nakong ya boimana le ya botswetse, netefatsa hore o sebedisa kgohlopo ha o etsa thobalano ho qoba ho tshwaetseha botjha.

src: if you have any problems such a painful nipples or breasts, be sure to go the clinic early for help.
tgt: haeba o ba le matswele kapa ditlhoko tse bohloko, potlaka o kope thuso tliliniking.

src: the department strongly recommends exclusive breastfeeding because it helps the baby develop a stronger immune system, and a stronger bond between mother and baby.
tgt: lefapha le kgothaletsa ho nyantsha letswele feela hobane le tiisa mmele wa lesea le ho tiisa dikamano pakeng tsa lona le motswetse.

src: breastfeeding also reduces the mother’s risks of developing breast cancer.
tgt: ho nyantsha ho boetse ho fokotsa menyetla ya hore mme a be le mofetshe wa letswele.

src: breastfeeding myths and facts there are several myths associated with breastfeeding, the department debunked these myths by answering the following frequently asked questions by mothers who are hiv positive and those who are not hiv positive.
tgt: nnete le leshano ka ho nyantsha ho na le ditaba tseo e seng nnete tse bolelwang ka ho nyantsha, lefapha le rata ho hlakisa seo e seng nnete ka ho araba dipotso tsena tse atisang ho botswa ke batswetse ba phelang le hiv le ba se nang yona.

src: question: my neighbour said that i should get some medicine to clean my baby's stomach.
tgt: potso: moahisane o itse ke reke moriana ho hlwekisa lesea ka maleng.

src: is this important?
tgt: na sena se bohlokwa?

src: answer: colostrum, which is the first form of breastmilk that is released by the mammary glands after giving birth, cleans the meconium from the stomach.
tgt: karabo: lebese la pele le tswang ho motswetse ka mora ho beleha, le kgona ho hlwekisa lesea ka maleng.

src: you will not need any medicines for further cleaning as breastmilk is clean, and actually lines the stomach, protecting it from bacteriaquestion: in the first few days, if i do not have enough milk, can i give water or other milk as well?
tgt: ka lebaka leo, ha o hloke moriana o mong ntle le lebese leo la letswele, le boelang le sireletse mpa ho dikokwanahloko.

src: answer: the colostrum is all the baby needs.
tgt: karabo: lebesenyana leo la pele, ke lona feela leo lesea le le hlokang.

src: you just need to feed the baby often so that the milk will come in you make lots of milk that way.
tgt: o tlameha ho le nyantsha kgafetsa hore lebese le kgone ho eketseha – ke yona tsela ya ho eketsa lebese.

src: ask the midwife to give you your baby within the first half hour after birth, so you can put the baby to the breast.
tgt: kopa mopepisi ho o neha lesea la hao halofong ya hora le hlahile hore o kgone ho le beha sefubeng.

src: the baby will learn quickly how to suckle and this will help you to make more milk.
tgt: lesea le tla potlaka ho ithuta ho nyanya mme seo se tla atisa le lebese.

src: question: i am giving breastmilk, but the baby is not satisfied.
tgt: potso: ke nyantsha lesea la ka, empa ha le kgore.

src: answer: no, you can make more milk by feeding the baby more often.
tgt: karabo: tjhe, o tla ba le lebese le le ngata ka ho nyantsa lesea kgafetsa.

src: allow the baby time to drink until satisfied on one breast to make sure the baby gets hindmilk which is the is the milk your baby gets at the end of a feed.
tgt: dumella lesea ho nyanya ho fihlela le kgora, le fumana lebese kaofela.

src: the more the baby suckles, the more milk is made.
tgt: ho nyantsha lesea kgafetsa, ho eketsa lebese.

src: question: my baby wants to feed so often maybe i don't have enough milk?
tgt: potso: lesea le batla ho nyanya kgafetsa, mohlomong ke hobane ha ke na lebese le lekaneng?

src: answer: maybe the baby is growing quickly, and so needs more milk.
tgt: karabo: mohlomong lesea la hao le hola ka potlako, jwale le hloka lebese le le ngata.

src: by feeding often, you can make enough milk for their needs.
tgt: ho nyantsha kgafetsa ho etsa o be le lebese le le ngata.

src: the milk will not run out.
tgt: lebese le ke se fele.

src: allow extra time for the baby to suckle don't pull the baby off the breast.
tgt: neha lesea nako e anetseng ya ho nyanya – o se ka phakisa ho le amoha letswele.

src: if a baby has more than six wet nappies every day, is being fed often (at least 812 times every day), and the baby is gaining at least 500g every month, then you are making enough milk.
tgt: haeba lesea la hao le hloka ho tjhentjhwa leleiri ho feta makgetlo a tsheletseng ka letsatsi, seo se bolela hore le nyanya hantle (bonyane makgetlo a robedi ho isa ho a 12 ka letsatsi) mme boima ba lona bo eketseha bonyane ka 500g ka kgwedi, seo se bontsha hore o na le lebese le lekaneng.

src: question: if my baby cries often, what do i do?
tgt: potso: ke etsa jwang haeba lesea la ka le lla kgafetsa?

src: answer: comfort your baby by putting them to the breast more often.
tgt: karabo: thudisa lesea la hao ka ho le beha sefubeng kgafetsa.

src: babies need to be close to their mothers.
tgt: masea a rata ho ba haufi le bo mma ona.

src: mothers and babies sharing the same room will encourage this.
tgt: mme le lesea ha ba dula ba le kamoreng e le nngwe ba kgothaletsa sena.

src: if your baby is hungry, thirsty or upset, suckling at the breast will satisfy them.
tgt: ha lesea le lapile, le nyorilwe kapa le kwatile, letswele le a le kgotsofatsa.

src: it is unlikely that you will overfeed your baby when giving breastmilk only.
tgt: ha ho atise ho etsahala hore lesea le nyanye tlolo ha le nyanya letswele feela.

src: question: is it good to give other drinks?
tgt: potso: ho molemo na ho le fa dino tse ding?

src: answer: no, adding other drinks means that the baby is more likely to get diseases like diarrhoea and pneumonia.
tgt: karabo: tjhe, ho le fa dino tse ding ho ka etsa hore lesea le be le ditshwaetso tse kang letshollo le nyomonia.

src: also, if the baby has other drinks, they won't suckle as often and you won't make enough milk.
tgt: ho lefa dino tse ding ho boetse ho etsa hore le se nyanye kgafetsa, e leng se tla etsa hore o se kgone ho ba le lebese le anetseng.

src: question: doesn't the baby need water when it is hot?
tgt: potso: na lesea ha le hloke metsi ha ho tjhesa?

src: answer: no, the first milk (foremilk) has lots of water and quenches the baby's thirst.
tgt: karabo: tjhe, lebese le tswang pele, le na le metsi mme le kgona ho nyorolla lesea.

src: jobs figures show our economyis on the road to recovery vukuzenzele unnamed over the last few years, south africans have had to contend with slow growth and rising unemployment.
tgt: dipalopalo tsa batho ba sebetseng di bontsha hore moruo wa rona o a hola vukuzenzele unnamed dilemong tse mmalwa tsa ho feta, palo ya batho ba sa sebetseng e ne e eketseha butle butle afrika borwa.

src: this has been worsened by a devastating pandemic, an attempted insurrection unrest in july 2021, and, earlier this year, severe floods in parts of kwazulunatal, eastern cape and north west.
tgt: maemo ana a ile a mpefatswa ke sewa sa covid19, merusu ya phupu 2021, ha mmoho le dikgohola tsa selemong sena karolong tsa kwazulunatal, kapa botjhabela le leboya bophirima.

src: amidst all this, the energy crisis has loomed large, causing damage to the economy and hardship for households and businesses.
tgt: hodima tsena tsohle, mathata a motlakase le ona a tlisitse mathata amang moruong, malapeng le dikgwebong.

src: yet, even amidst these formidable challenges, our society and economy has proven to be resilient.
tgt: leha ho le jwalo, se tjhaba le moruo wa rona di kgonne ho mamella sena.

src: and indications are that our economy is showing encouraging signs of recovery.
tgt: moruo wa rona jwale o bontsha ho ntlafala.

src: the latest employment figures, in particular, give us grounds for cautious hope.
tgt: dipalopalo tsa batho ba sebetsang di fana ka tshepo ya ho ntlafala ha maemo.

src: statistics south africa recorded a decline in the unemployment rate for the second quarter of 2021. significantly, their measurement shows that the actual number of people employed rose from 14.5 million people in the fourth quarter of 2021 to 15.5 million in the second quarter of 2022. this is an encouraging increase of muchneeded jobs over the first half of this year.
tgt: lefapha la dipalopalo afrika borwa le bontshitse ha palo ya batho ba sa sebetseng e theohile ka kotara ya bobedi ya 2021. dipalopalo tsa bona di bontshitse hore palo ya batho ba sebetsang e eketsehile ho tloha ho ba dimilione di 14.5 ka kotara ya bone ya 2021 ho fihlela ho ba dimilione di 15.5 ka kotara ya bobedi ya 2022. ena ke keketseho eo re neng re e hloka ya mesebetsi halofong ya pele ya selemo sena.

src: these jobs were mainly created in sectors such as community and social services, trade, finance and, notably, construction.
tgt: mesebetsi ena e fumanehile makaleng a kang la ditshebeletso tsa setjhaba, la dikgwebo, ditjhelete le la kaho.

src: of course, much more needs to be done if we are to make a significant dent in our country’s high unemployment rate.
tgt: leha ho le jwalo, o sa le mo ngata mosebetsi o sa ntsaneng o tlameha ho etsuwa haeba re batla ho fokotsa leqeme la mesebetsi.

src: at the same time, these figures indicate that the priority areas of the economic reconstruction and recovery plan – such as mass public employment, economic reform and infrastructure development – are having an impact on job creation.
tgt: dipalopalo tsena di bo ntsha ho sebetsa ha lenaneo la tsoseletso le kahobotjha ya moruo – dikarolong tse kang kgirong ya batho ka bongata, kahong botjha ya moruo le ntshetso pele ya meralo ya motheo – jwalo ka ha e le tsona tse bileng le kabelo e kgolo menyetleng ena ya mesebetsi.

src: with infrastructure development and investment being one of the key priorities of our recovery plan, the growth in jobs in the construction area is particularly encouraging.
tgt: leha ntshetso pele ya meralo ya motheo le matsete e le tsona tse pele kahong botjha ya moruo, empa ho a kgothatsa ho bona keketseho makaleng a kang la kaho.

src: the february 2022 budget outlined a 30% increase in spending on public infrastructure over the next three years to r812 billion, compared to r627 billion over the past three years.
tgt: puong ya kabo ya matlotlo ka hlakola 2022, ho ile ha hlaka hore mmuso o ekeditse tjhelete e ka bang persente tse 30 ntlafatsong ya meralo ya motheo dilemong tsena tse tharo tse tlang ya ya ho dibilione tse r812, ha e bapiswa le dibilione tse r627 dilemong tse tharo tsa ho feta.

src: the construction industry development board recently noted that there has been an increase in infrastructure projects driven by stateowned enterprises like transnet and eskom, but also in the metros and through the department of public works and infrastructure.
tgt: boto ya ntshetsopele ya indasteri ya tsa kaho e boletse ha ho na le keke tseho diprojekeng tsa kaho ya meralo ya motheo dikgwebong tsa mmuso tse kang transnet le eskom, le ho bommasepala ba baholo.

src: in june, this year we saw our economy return to prepandemic growth levels owing to a fairly positive gdp outcome in the first quarter of the year.
tgt: sena se bakilwe ke kgolo tlhahisong ya thepa kotareng ya pele ya selemo.

src: naturally the objective is to move significantly off this low base, which is why we are continuing with our focus on structural reforms that drive growth.
tgt: maikemisetso a maholo ke ho o phahamisa haholo, e leng se etsang hore re tsepamise tshebetso meralong ya metheo e leng yona e thusang kgolong ya ona.

src: government recently published a proposed amendment to remove the licensing threshold for electricity generation facilities and encourage investment in larger, utility scale projects to rapidly add new generation capacity to the grid.
tgt: mmuso o sa tswa pha tlalatsa taba ya ho eketsa tekanyetso eo laesense ya tlhahiso ya motlakase e e dumellang ho bahlahisi ba ikemetseng e tla tlisa keketseho diprojekeng tsa tlhahiso ya motlakase, e le se tla eketsa motlakase o hokelwang phepelong.

src: this represents a major milestone in our efforts to transform the country’s energy landscape, a critical prerequisite for economic growth and attracting investment.
tgt: ena e tla ba katleho e kgolo matsapeng a rona a ho rarolla mathata a motlakase, e leng sa bohlokwa kgolong ya moruo le ho hoheleng bo ramatsete.

src: since the national energy plan was announced in july this year, we have been working as government in partnership with various stakeholders on implementation and policy reform.
tgt: ka phupu selemong sena ho phatlaladitswe leano la naha la eneji mme, mmuso jwale o sebedisana le bankakarolo ba fapafapaneng ho le kenya tshebetsong.

src: since we raised the licensing threshold to 100 megawatts in june 2021, more than 500 mw of private renewable power generation projects have been registered, with a pipeline of over 6,000 mw of projects at various stages of development.
tgt: haesale re eketsa teka nyetso ya tlhahiso ya motlakase eo laesense e e dumellang e ba 100 megawatts ka phuptjane 2021, re se re fumane bahlahisi ba ikemetseng ba tla hlahisa 500 mw mme ho na le diprojeke tse ding tse ka etsang 6 000 mw tse tlang.

src: the structural reform process continues to register progress in support of economic growth and attracting investment.
tgt: ntlafatso ya meralo ya motheo le yona e tswela pele ho tshehetsa kgolo ya moruo le ho hohela bo ramatsete.

src: economic growth cannot be realised and jobs cannot be created without undertaking the difficult but necessary structural reforms that will improve the business and investment climate.
tgt: moruo o ke ke wa hola mme le mesebetsi e ke ke ya ba teng haeba re sa rarolle taba ya meralo ya motheo e leng yona e tla thusa kgolong ya moruo le matsete.

src: this is government’s role.
tgt: sena ke ona mosebetsi o moholo wa mmuso.

src: however for success to be guaranteed, we will need to forge consensus between business, labour and civil society not only on the reforms that are needed, but on the tradeoffs that are necessary to achieve our goals.
tgt: hore re kgone ho atleha ho sena, ho tlameha ho ba le tumellano pakeng tsa mmuso, setjhaba le mekgatlo ya basebetsi, e seng ka diphetoho tse tlamehang ho etswa feela, empa le hore re tlameha ho etsa jwang ho ka fihlela ditoro tsa rona.
